dialog.addelement: Добавление ссылки на элемент; Слои глифов содержат элементы. Один и тот же элемент может использоваться в нескольких слоях глифов. Если добавить ссылку на элемент в текущем глифе, новый элемент в глифе будет связан с тем же элементом в других глифах — если изменить ее в одном месте, она изменится везде. Ссылки на именованные элементы отображаются на панели **Галерея**. **Чтобы найти элемент или глиф для добавления в качестве ссылки**, необходимо ввести его имя в поле фильтра. Используйте кнопки Глифы и Элементы , расположенные в левом нижнем углу диалогового окна **, это даст возможность выбрать, что необходимо отображать в диалоговом окне только элементы, только глифы или и то, и другое** **Чтобы использовать предварительную ширину добавленного элемента**, необходимо выбрать опцию Заменить предварительную ширину. В противном случае необходимо оставить опцию Сохранить метрики. **Чтобы добавить ссылку на элемент или компонент**, необходимо выбрать элемент или глиф в диалоговом окне и нажать кнопку OK.
dialog.addglyphs: Добавление глифов; Диалоговое окно **Добавить глифы** можно использовать для добавления к шрифту стандартных форм глифов в кодировке Unicode. В диалоговом окне, в виде сетки, отображается список всех глифов Юникода, известных FontLab. В серых ячейках содержатся глифы, которые уже существуют в шрифте и не могут быть выбраны. Можно выбрать любой из оставшихся глифов (или все). **Чтобы добавить глиф **, необходимо выбрать его на панели. **Чтобы выбрать все доступные глифы**, следует нажать опцию Выбрать все. **Чтобы добавить глиф**, следует выбрать его в диалоговом окне, и затем нажать Применить. **Чтобы добавить глиф и закрыть диалоговое окно**, следует нажать OK. По умолчанию вновь добавленные глифы будут отмечены синим цветом. **Чтобы изменить цвет флага**, следует использовать выпадающее меню в левом нижнем углу диалогового окна. **Чтобы снять цветовой флаг для вновь добавленного глифа(ов)**, необходимо использовать опцию Отметить новые глифы. **Чтобы отфильтровать глифы, которые отображаются в диалоговом окне**, необходимо выбрать одну из опций, расположенные в левом верхнем углу. Опции состоят из переключателей. Для переключения предусмотрено три варианта: 1. В ** Интеллектуальном** режиме, можно ввести **имя скрипта и/или категорию или какое-либо другое слово, объединяющее несколько символов Юникода**. В FontLab будут отображены глифы, соответствующие введенным ранее ключевым словам. 2. В режиме **Категории** будет отображен список категорий глифов, таких как Буквы в верхнем регистре, Математические символы или Частное использование. Выбор одной из категорий приведет к отображению справа всех глифов. Большинство не латинских символов находятся в группе Другие символы, поэтому, если необходимы выбрать не латинские символы, следует использовать вкладку Скрипты для получения конкретных результатов. 3. В режиме **Скрипты** отображается длинный **список всех доступных скриптов Юникод**. Чтобы просмотреть все доступные символы в списке необходимо кликнуть на одном из скриптов в списке.
dialog.addlayer: Add Layer; The **Add Layer** dialog can be used to add a new layer or master. The dialog has the following fields and options: - **Name**, where you can enter a name for the new layer. - A set of three icons to define the main **Properties** of this layer — whether it will be a service layer, be locked and if it will be displayed as wireframe. By default, a new layer will be added at the top of the list in the panel. **To put the new layer at the bottom of the list**, click the Put to background button. - You can choose whether the new layer should be added to the current glyph only, selected glyphs or all glyphs. - By default, if a layer already exists, it will not be added and the option Skip will be selected. **To add the layer even if it exists**, select Add anyway. - **Fill new layer with content of this font** allows you to copy glyph elements from another opened font to the new layer of the current font, and choose whether you would like this copy to be left, right or center aligned. You can also choose the master of that font. If no other font is open at the time, the contents of the currently selected layer of the same font will be copied. - Check the **Make it master layer** if you would like FontLab to name the master in a way that it works as a master. This will be a font master if you add the contents of the opened font, or this a glyph master if you create the layer for just some of the glyphs in the font. - If **Use instance layer if available** is checked and the font is axis-based (i.e. a variable font), the #instance layer is used. - If **Reuse named elements that exist in new font layer** is checked elements having names will be used. - Check the **Rasterize layer to this PPM** and enter the value you need to put the result of the glyphs outline rasterisation to the new layer.
dialog.addsuffixtoname: Add Suffix to Name; The **Add Suffix to Name** dialog can be used to rename selected glyphs by either adding a new suffix or changing the existing glyph name suffix. **To enter a new suffix**, type it in the Name field or use the suffix dropdown menu to select the standard suffixes for glyphs used in OpenType features. **To replace the current suffix of the selected glyphs**, check the Replace existing suffix option. Click Ok to apply the changes.
dialog.commands: Commands; The **Commands** dialog can be used to assign keyboard shortcuts to menu commands, and to execute commands. **To find a command**, type its name in the Search field. Note that this dialog only shows seventy-five commands, so not every command is visible by default. **To define a new keyboard shortcut**, select the command in the list and position the cursor on the editing field below the list. When the caret is in position in the field, press the combination of keys that you want to assign. A description of that combination will appear in the editing field, and you can click the Set button **to assign that combination to the currently selected command**. If that keyboard shortcut you have entered is already being used for another command, that command’s name will appear under the editing field in red, and the Set button will appear disabled. The button will also be disabled if you only press a single key. **To remove the existing keyboard shortcut for a command**, select the command in the list, and click Clear. **To reset all FontLab keyboard shortcuts to factory defaults**, click the hamburger menu button and select Reset Shortcuts. **To import keyboard shortcuts**, click the hamburger menu button and select Import Custom Shortcuts…. A standard Open dialog will appear where you can choose the appropriate file to import. **To export keyboard shortcuts**, click the hamburger menu button and select Export Custom Shortcuts…. A standard Save dialog will appear. Note that exported keyboard shortcuts are saved in a JSON file. **To save changes and close the dialog**, click Close in the dialog. **To save the changes and also execute the selected command**, click Go or press ↩.
dialog.exportfonts: Экспорт шрифтов; Диалоговое окно **Экспорт шрифтов** предназначено для выбора формата экспорта для разработанного шрифта, и директории для его сохранения. **Чтобы выбрать формат шрифта**, выберите один из Профилей для экспорта, расположенные на панели слева. В списке предусмотрены только активные профили для экспорта, которые были включены в диалоговом окне Профили. В него можно перейти с помощью пункта меню Файл › Профили. В FontLab предусмотрены собственные форматы, в которых хранится весь исходный шрифт (.vfc и .vfj), DesignSpace + UFO и вариации OpenType - это профили с несколькими начертаниями. Все остальные профили относятся к профилям с одинарным начертанием шрифтов. Если вы выберете профиль “с одинарным начертанием”, вам нужно будет выбрать, какое содержимое исходного шрифта следует экспортировать. **Чтобы выбрать, какой контент следует экспортировать в профиль с одинарным начертанием**, используйте переключатель Текущий слой / Экземпляры / Мастера. Переключатель предусматривает следующие опции: 1. Если вы выберете **Текущий слой** в качестве содержимого шрифта, то FontLab-ом будет экспортирован текущий активный мастер или слой из вашего исходного шрифта. 2. В списке **Экземпляры** отображаются все предопределенные экземпляры, которые были заданы в диалоговом окне Информация о шрифте, в которое можно перейти через пункт меню Файл › Информация о шрифте › Экземпляры. **Чтобы включить/отключить предопределенные экземпляры, которые вы хотите экспортировать**, используйте переключатели, расположенные в окне слева. Все включенные экземпляры будут сгенерированы с помощью интерполяции, а затем экспортированы в виде отдельных шрифтов. 3. Если в вашем исходном шрифте содержится несколько основных шрифтов, вы можете выбрать **Мастера** в качестве содержимого шрифта. В списке мастеров будут показаны все мастера шрифтов, которые вы задали в диалоговом окне Информация о шрифте, в которое можно перейти через пункт меню Файл › Информация о шрифте › Мастера. **Чтобы включить/отключить мастеров, которые вы хотите экспортировать**, используйте переключатели, расположенные в окне слева. Все включенные шаблоны будут экспортированы в виде отдельных шрифтов. **Чтобы выбрать директорию для сохранения экспортированных шрифтов**, используйте параметры в разделе Директория, расположенные в нижней части диалогового окна: - Выберите **Источник**, если хотите экспортировать свои шрифты в ту же папку, в которой сохранен ваш исходный шрифт. - Или воспользуйтесь опциями **Папка** и **Выбрать**, чтобы выбрать папку, в которую будут экспортированы ваши шрифты. Для **автоматического создания структуры вложенных папок внутри целевой папки**, активируйте опцию Семейство. **Для создания структуры вложенных папок на основе выбранного профиля для экспорта**, установите флаг Профиль. FontLab автоматически создаст имена файлов для экспортируемых шрифтов на основе “наилучшей совместимости”. Вы можете использовать раскрывающийся список Существующие файлы шрифтов, чтобы решить, что необходимо сделать с файлами с такими же именами, которые уже существуют в целевой папке. После того, как вы выбрали нужный вам вариант, нажмите Экспорт**, для осуществления экспорта шрифтов**.
dialog.findglyphs: Поиск глифов; Диалоговое окно **Поиск глифов** можно использовать для поиска глифов с помощью введенных ключевых слов и нескольких заданных критериев. **Чтобы найти глиф**, необходимо ввести ключевое(ые) слова в поле Поиск. В зависимости от того, что будет введено, в списке слева будут отображать различные критерии. **Чтобы выбрать глиф**, кликните по нем в списке (или выберите несколько глифов, с помощью нажатой клавишу  SHIFT or Cmd). **Чтобы выбрать все глифы**, нажмите кнопку Выбрать глифы в списке, она расположена в правом верхнем углу. Если вы находитесь в окне Шриты, то при 2×КЛИКЕ на выбранным глифам приведет к закрытию диалогового окна и **выбранные глифы будут отображены в окне Шрифты**. Если вы находились в окне Глифы, то необходимо проделать действия, описанные выше, вследствие чего **выбранные глифы будут открыты в окне Глифов**.
dialog.findoutline: Найти контур; Диалоговое окно **Найти контур** в сочетании с командой Редактировать › Копировать поможет вам заменить один или несколько идентичных контуров, встречающихся в нескольких глифах, на альтернативные варианты.**Чтобы увидеть, в каких глифах присутствует конкретный контур или часть контура**, выделите его в одном глифе с помощью инструмента Контур, а затем откройте диалоговое окно **Найти контур**, перейдя в пункт меню Правка › Найти контур или используя сочетание клавиш Ctrl+F. В диалоговом окне нажмите Найти, чтобы увидеть глиф, содержащий контур или часть контура.**Чтобы выполнить операцию поиска и замены контура или части контура**, выполните следующие действия:1. Выберите контур(ы). 2. Скопируйте выделенный фрагмент в буфер обмена с помощью команды Правка › Копировать. 3. Измените исходную форму по своему желанию и выберите новый вариант. 4. Откройте диалоговое окно **Найти контур**, с помощью пункта меню Правка › Найти контур или используйте сочетание клавиш Ctrl+F. С левой стороны панели будет отображен путь, по которому FontLab будет осуществляться поиск, а с правой стороны панели будет показан путь, который будет использоваться в качестве замены. 5. На левой стороны панели нажмите Вставить из буфера обмена, а на правой нажмите Использовать текущий выбор. 6. Нажмите Найти, чтобы осуществить поиск следующий исходный путь в одном из глифов. Первый, найденный такой глиф появится в окне Глифы и будет выбран найденный путь. 7. Нажмите Заменить, чтобы заменить старый путь на новый, или нажмите Заменить и найти, чтобы заменить и найти следующий пути.**Чтобы выбрать, с какими глифами необходимо выполнить данную операция**, используйте раскрывающийся список Применить к.По умолчанию измененные глифы будут окрашены, синим цветом. **Чтобы изменить цвет флага**, воспользуйтесь выпадающим меню в диалоговом окне, которое расположено в левом нижнем углу. **Чтобы не применять цвет для измененных символов**, снимите флаг Флаг для результата.
dialog.fontinfo: Информация о шрифте; Диалоговое окно Информация о шрифте - это область, в котором вы можете определять свойства для шрифта. На локальной панель инструментов будут отображены свойства, какие заданы для шрифта. Используйте стрелки влево и вправо, чтобы внести изменения в текущий шрифт и отредактировать свойства для предыдущего или следующего шрифта соответственно. Вы также можете выбрать, какие свойства для шрифта необходимо отображать, воспользовавшись выпадающим меню Шрифт и Мастера. Поле **Найти** можно использовать для поиска вложенных свойств на панели. На панели диалогового окна предусмотрено три кнопки: Отмена, Применить и ОК. Используйте кнопку Применить перед нажатием на кнопку ОК , чтобы применить текущие изменения к открытому шрифту. Чтобы изменить свойства, следует выбрать раздел, расположенный на панели слева.
dialog.fontinfo.axes: Font Info > Axes; In Font Info › Axes, you can define axes that are typographic properties that change during interpolation. Axes form the coordinate system for your font design space. If you have two standard default axes – weight and width – you may have this page empty and still be able to design two-dimensional variations. But if you need to change default axes or add more axes to your design space you need to use this section of the dialog. To create a new axis, click the plus-shaped **Add axis** button. Select one among several predefined axes or choose the “Custom” one. When a new axis appears you can change its properties: * In the **Name** field, add the name of the axes. * Enter the **FontLab-internal two-letter axis code** in this field. This code will be used within the application while working on variable fonts. If you are adding a custom axis, change the code to something unique. * Enter the **four-letter axis tag** in this field. The standard registered axes from the OpenType specification are Weight, Width, Optical size, Slant and Italic. If you are adding a custom axis, change the code to something unique. * Use the **Show/hide in the apps** toggle to specify whether this axes should be visible other applications’ UI. * Put in the **Minimum**, **Maximum** and **Default** coordinates for the axis in the respective fields. Use the **Auto range** button to automatically generate these range values. * Use the **Instances** field to enter recipes for instances along this axis, or use the **Auto instances** button to generate these recipes automatically. To remove an axis, select it in the list and click the minus-shaped **Remove axis** button. Select **Sort Contours and Start Nodes** to ensure that when you add existing fonts as masters, FontLab will sort contours and points on the fly when fonts are added to make the order of elements, contours and points consistent. This operation assumes that both masters have the same number of nodes (only on-curve and TT off-curve points, not handles). Select **Check masters geometry** to detect if there are problems with types of nodes (smooth/sharp), types of segments (line/curve) and take care of situations where elements have been rotated. If something is wrong with nodes and contours compatibility FontLab will try to fix this automatically.
dialog.fontinfo.codepages: Font Info > Codepages; Use the Font Info › Codepages section to specify the list of codepages that the font supports, as specified in the OS/2 table. **To select supported codepages automatically**, click the Detect codepages button. FontLab will analyze the Unicode information available in the font and will automatically detect which codepages this font can support. **To add a codepage to the list of supported codepages**, select a codepage in the list on the left, and press the Add codepage button. **To remove a codepage from the list of supported codepages**, select a codepage in the list on the right, and press the Remove codepage button. **To reset the list of supported codepages**, click the Reset button. **To edit the CodePageRange1 and CodePageRange2 values of the OS/2 font table directly**, use the field below the selected codepages.
dialog.fontinfo.creator: Font Info > Creator; In Font Info › Creator, you can edit the font description, designer and vendor credits. It has the following options: **Vendor Code** is an up-to-four letter length code that is assigned to TrueType producers, which must be registered with Microsoft. All registered **Vendor Names** known at the time of FontLab release are placed in the drop-down list box next to the vendor code field. Start typing the vendor name and you will see the drop-down list box. If you want to identify yourself without registering you may enter a lowercase four-letter vendor code. In **Vendor URL**, you can add the web site address for the vendor. click the Open in browser button to open the website in your browser. Use the **Designer** field to enter the name of the designer(s) of the typeface family. In **Designer URL**, enter the web site address for the designer. click the Open in browser button to open the website in your browser. Put the name of the font manufacturer in the **Manufacturer** field. Use **Creation date** to enter the year and time when the font was created. The year is used to automatically fill in the Copyright field and is exported in OpenType-TT fonts as the Creation year entry. Under **Version**, you can enter the major and minor version numbers and click the Auto button to generate the version string. The **Description** field is exported in PostScript Type 1 fonts as the Copyright entry, and in TrueType fonts as the Description entry. Enter the approriate text in this field based on the type of font you are creating.
dialog.fontinfo.familydimensions: Font Info > Family Dimensions; In the Family Dimensions section of Font Info you can edit those font metrics that must be identical in all fonts of the same font family: **Units Per em** is the number of font units that defines the font height and the coordinate grid on which the glyphs are drawn. To modify the UPM, press the Change button, which will bring up a dialog where you can enter the new UPM value. Choose **Scale glyphs and metrics to the new UPM value option** and all the font data will be scaled automatically. Enter the position of the font’s ascender line in the **Ascender** field. Enter the position of the font’s descender line in the **Descender** field. In the **Line Gap** field, enter the line gap value, i.e. the distance between bottom line of the upper line of text and top line of the lower line of text. In the **Safe Top** field, define the topmost line of all non-exceptional characters in the font. In the **Safe Bottom** field, define the lowermost line of all non-exceptional characters in the font. Enter the topmost position of all characters in the font in the **BBox top** field. Enter the lowest position of all characters in the font in the **BBox bottom** field. You can use the Copy dimensions and Paste dimensions buttons on the bottom-right of the dialog to copy/paste all the family dimensions from another font.
dialog.fontinfo.fontdimensions: Font Info > Font Dimensions; In the Font Dimensions section of Font Info, you can modify the following properties: Enter the height of the font’s uppercase characters in **Caps Height**. Enter the height of the lowercase characters in **X Height**. In the **Italic Angle**, enter the actual italic or oblique angle for the font. The italic angle is measured in the counterclockwise direction, but FontLab shows it positive here. So the default value is 12º. Use this field if you are creating an italic font. The **Slope** value is based on the Italic Angle and used to calculate the slope of the cursor. In the **Caret Offset** field, enter the amount by which a slanted highlight on a glyph needs to be shifted to produce the best appearance. Non-slanted fonts should have a setting of zero. **Curve tension** is a measure of how much a curve deviates from a straight line between two points. Enter a value between 0 to 100% in this field. **Corner Tension** is the tension applied to all Smart Corners in the master. **Ink-trap Width** controls the amount that the corners or details are removed from the letterforms, when using Smart Corners. Use the **U-Position** and **U-Thickness** to define the position of the middle and the thickness of the underline line in your font. You can use the Copy dimensions and Paste dimensions buttons on the bottom-right of the dialog to copy/paste all the font dimensions from another font.
dialog.fontinfo.guides: Font Info > Guides; In Font Info › Guides, you can view, create and manage font guides. The dialog shows you all the font guides in your font in a list, along with their Name, Position, Expression, Width and Tags. **To edit a guide or its properties**, 2×CLICK the appropriate cell and type the new value. **To add a new font guide**, click the plus-shaped Add guide button and then edit the appropriate values. **To remove a font guide**, select it in the list and click the minus-shaped Remove guide button.
dialog.fontinfo.instances: Font Info > Instances; In Font Info › Instances, you can view and declare predefined instances in your variable font. The predefined axes are displayed in a table with checkboxes to select whether they are active or not, a preview, as well as their Style, Style Group and Location. To add new predefined instance to your variable font, click the plus-shaped **Add axis** button at the bottom of the list of instances. The new default instance will be added and you can change its properties. To remove the instance from your variable font, select it in the list and click the minus-shaped **Remove axis** button. click the **From Axes** button to automatically generate predefined instances based on the recipes specified in Font Info › Axes. click the **From Masters** button to automatically generate predefined instances for each master. click **Reset** to remove all predefined instances. To edit instance properties, select the instance in the list and refer to the properties section below the list: * In **Style** enter the style of the font, and use the **Weight** and **Width** dropdowns and fields to define those attributes. * Use the **Location** field to define the what overall location the instance takes in the design space formed by axes, or use the **Axes** dropdowns and fields below it to change the location per axes. Changes made in either fields will automatically reflect in the other. * Click the arrow on the left of the Location field, to open more details about the **Styling Group**.
dialog.fontinfo.legal: Font Info > Legal; In the Font Info › Legal section, you can enter copyright and licensing information about your typeface. Enter the copyright notice in the **Copyright** field. It must include the © symbol or the word “Copyright”, the name of the company or person that owns the copyright and the copyright year. In the **Trademark** field, enter the font’s trademark notice. In the **License URL** field, enter a web site address for the License if any. Put the font license or EULA in the **License** field. Use the **Embedding** dropdown menu to select how the font file will be included in electronic documents like PDF or a webpage. Turn the **Allow subsetting** option off to not allow subsetting of the embedded font. Turn the **Bitmap embedding only** option on to not allow embedding of font outlines but integrate fonts as bitmaps.
dialog.fontinfo.masters: Font Info > Masters; The Font Info › Masters section is where you can change your font master's properties. It contains a full list of all the font masters in a table. To add new font master to your variable font, click the plus-shaped **Add master** button at the bottom of the list at the left of the dialog. The dropdown menu allows you to select the method of creating new master. To remove the font master from your variable font, click the minus-shaped **Remove master** button at the bottom of the list at the left of the dialog. Click the checkbox to the left of a master’s name to make it the default master. Click the **AAA** button to the right of the master’s name and location to select it (button becomes blue) to specify that it should be used for interpolation. If this button is not selected, the master will not be used for interpolation. Select a master in the list to edit its propoerties that are shown below the table: * Under **Attributes**, you can edit the **Weight**, **Width** and **Slope** using the respective dropdowns or the Weight field. Additionally, you can specify some way in which a style of your font differs that is not weight, width or slope in the **Other** field. * In the **Location** field, enter the value for the master’s location; or use the **Axes** field below that to do the same.
dialog.fontinfo.names: Font Info > Names; In the Names section of the Font Info dialog you can edit the following properties: **Family Name** or typographic family name is the field for the name under which all fonts from one family are grouped in the font menu of a modern application. The name should be no more than 31 characters, and it is recommended that only uppercase and lowercase English letters, spaces and numerals are used. Use the **Weight** dropdown menu to select the typographic weight of the typeface. This can range between Thin (100) to Extra Black (950), and defaulting to Regular (400). Use the **Width** dropdown to select the typographic width of a typeface, ranging from Ultra Condensed to Ultra Expanded, and defaulting to Normal for most fonts. Select **Monospaced** if you are designing a monospaced typeface. Use the **Slope** dropwdown menu define whether the typeface is upright, italic or oblique. In **Other**, specify some way in which a style of your font differs that is not weight, width or slope. **Style** or the typographic style name is the field for the name under which a certain font within a family appears in the font menu of modern applications. Use the Auto button to generate the field automatically. **Full Name** or Full font name is the field for a more detailed font name. It is sometimes used by applications to refer to a font by its name. Use the Auto button to generate the field automatically. In the **PostScript** field, enter the PostScript name is a name used internally by a PostScript printer to identify the font within a printing job. Its length cannot exceed 29 characters, and it must only consist of uppercase or lowercase English letters or digits. Use the Auto button to generate the field automatically. In **Style group** field, enter the Styling group name, which is the name that appears in older Windows applications as the “Family” or “Font” name. Use the Auto button to generate the field automatically. Use the **Style link** dropdown to choose between “Regular”, “Italic”, “Bold”, “Bold Italic”, which are used as the name which appears as the name of the “Font style” in a font selection menu in applications that do not support Typographic families. Press the **Build Names** button to to automatto automatically generate the Full name, PostScript name and Style group name fields. If you designed several font masters for your variable font, you can rename them here using the **Master name field**. Master name is identical to the layer name where the master lives. If you rename a master, the change is instantly visible in the top and bottom-left master selectors.
dialog.fontinfo.note: Font Info > Note; In the Note section of Font Info, you can add any internal design comments, which will not be exported in the final font.
dialog.fontinfo.othervalues: Font Info > Other Values; In Font Info › Other Values, you can define additional technical font master properties. Under **Font Dimensions**, you can control the X and Y coordinates and size of the **superscript** and **subscript** characters, as well as the position and the width of the **strikeout line**. In **Family Dimensions**, you can define **platform-specific linespacing** settings for the entire font family. Under **PostScript Hinting**, you can define extra parameters to control the PostScript hinting (CFF, Type 1) of the font: * If **ForceBold** is turned on, PS hinting algorithm makes the font looking “bold.” * **BlueScale** controls PPM when overshoot depression is switched off. If PPM is less than BlueScale, then overshoot suppression is applied. If it is equal to or exceeds BlueScale, overshoot suppression works only if the distance from the aligned point to the base line of the alignment zone is less than the BlueShift value and the scaled distance is less then half of a pixel. * **BlueShift** gives more precise control over overshoot description. * **BlueFuzz** lets you expand alignment zones in both directions. If you have defined a zone like (700-715), and BlueFuzz is equal to 2, then the actual zone used will be (698-717). **TrueType Hinting and Smoothing** controls the hinting process and antialiasing parameters of a TrueType font: * From the **Use TT hinting** dropdown, select among FontLab TrueType hinting algorithms, TTFAutohint, and no hinting for this particular font. * If you enter 0 in **No smoothing up to PPM**, smoothing will be on for all PPMs. * If you enter 0 in **No vertical smoothing up to PPM**, vertical smoothing will be on for all PPMs.
dialog.fontinfo.parameters: Font Info > Parameters; In Font Info › Parameters, you can manage parameters, which are named numeric variables that are used in expressions. Values you can reference in expressions font-wide — parameters, font guidelines and selected variables — are listed in this section. Variables are preceded by three grey dotted horizontal lines; parameters by a calculator; and font guidelines by two horizontal blue dotted line intersected by a vertical one. **To define a new parameter**, click the plus-shaped Add parameter button, name the variable and DRAG the slider to define its value. **To remove an existing parameter**, select it in the list and click the minus-shaped Remove parameter button. **To modify the value of a parameter**, enter the new value in the input area, use the number steppers or the slider. Note that changing the value of a pre-defined variable will also change your font’s dimensions listed on other pages.
dialog.fontinfo.stems: Font Info > Stems; In Font Info › Stems, you can control the vertical standard stems that correspond to x-direction hinting, as well as the horizontal PS standard stems that correspond to y-direction hinting. The table in the dialog shows the Name, Width and Tags of the stems. Click the diamond-shaped **Auto-detect stems** to automatically build a list of standard stems found in the font. This will be done by analyzing the PS hint values found in the font, which means that the font needs to have hinting. 2×CLICK any of the stems in the table to edit the information. Use the **Add horizontal stem** or **Add vertical stem** buttons to add horizontal or vertical stems perfectly. 2×CLICK the newly added entry to edit the details. Use the **Remove stem** button to delete a stem selected in the table. Select **Horizontal Stems**, **Vertical Stems** or both to choose whether which ones to edit in the text boxes above. Use the **Copy stems** or **Paste stems** buttons at the bottom-right to copy or paste all the stems from one font to another.
dialog.fontinfo.unicoderanges: Font Info > Unicode Ranges; Use the Font Info › Unicode Ranges section to specify the supported Unicode ranges in the font, as specified in the OS/2 table. **To select supported Unicode ranges automatically**, click the Detect Unicode ranges button. FontLab will analyze the Unicode information available in the font and will automatically detect which unicode ranges this font supports. **To add a Unicode range to the list of supported ranges**, select a Unicode range in the list. **To remove a Unicode range to the list of supported ranges**, uncheck it in the list. **To reset the list of supported Unicode ranges**, click the Remove all selected Unicode ranges button. Use the Filter field below the list to search for a Unicode range.
dialog.fontinfo.zones: Font Info > Zones; In Font Info › Zones, you can define zones or areas where hinting will align points. The dialog is divided into two: the table on the left shows top zones, and on the right shows bottom zones. Each table shows the Name, Position, Height and Tags. Use the **Local zones / Family zones** toggle to choose whether you want to edit zones locally or for the entire family. Click the diamond-shaped Auto-detect zones **to automatically (re)build alignment zones** for the font. FontLab will do so by analyzing the bounding boxes of a hardcoded list of uppercase and lowercase English letters. To add a top or bottom zone, click the appropriate plus-shaped **Add zone** button, and then 2×CLICK the newly added entry to edit the details. To remove a top or bottom zone, select it in the list and click the appropriate minus-shaped **Remove zone** button. Use the **Copy zones** or **Paste zones** buttons at the bottom-right to copy or paste all the zones from one font to another.
dialog.generateglyphs: Generate Glyphs; The Generate Glyphs dialog is used to generate new glyphs with greater control than the Add Glyphs command. With Generate Glyphs, you can choose whether the resulting glyphs should be simple, composite or auto glyphs. In the dialog’s status bar, you can select between five options: Characters, Ligature, Variants, Precomposed and Custom. The first four tabs work based on a selection in the Font Window or Glyph Window. The Custom tab allows you to type or paste your own glyph recipes using a special syntax. Use the **Size** dropdown to change the size of the preview text string at the bottom of the dialog. On the left of the dialog, you can control the following: * Select **Use anchors** to make use of any anchors you have created in the source glyphs to position them together. This is usually desirable, and is most commonly used for better positioning of diacritical marks (accents). * Select **Link as references** to create the generated glyphs using References to the Elements in the original glyphs. This too is commonly used for accented glyphs, and sometimes for ligatures as long as no changes are needed to the elements. * Select **Rebuild existing glyphs** to overwrite existing glyphs if the newly added glyphs have the same names. * Select **Create auto layers** to generate the glyphs as auto glyphs: elements will be added as references, anchors will be used to position them if present in the primary glyphs, the advance width will be inherited from the base glyphs, and the contents of the generated glyphs will automatically fill and update over time as you add new base and mark glyphs. The recipes that you’ve used to generate the auto glyphs will be copied into the glyph recipe field of the glyphs’ auto layers. * When **Open new glyphs for editing** is turned on, FontLab will generate the requested glyphs and then immediately open them for editing in a new Glyph window. When turned off, FontLab will just generate the glyphs. At the bottom of the dialog, in the status bar, select **Flag new glyphs** and use the adjoining **Color** dropdown to color-code the cells for your newly-generated glyphs. Click **OK** to generate glyphs.
dialog.generateglyphs.characters: Generate Glyphs > Characters; To generate glyphs using Generate Glyphs › Characters, first select them in the Font window or type/paste/select a string in the Glyph window using the Text tool, and then open this tab of the dialog. FontLab will try to **generate a glyph for every character of your input selection**. Eg: if your input selection was the text `fön`, FontLab will try to generate the glyphs `f`, `odieresis` and `n`.
dialog.generateglyphs.custom: Generate Glyphs > Custom; In Font › Generate Glyphs › Custom: - Put multiple glyph names in one or more lines to use built-in glyph recipes. - Turn **on** Use simple (FLS5) syntax and put each glyph recipe in a separate line to mix both simple and extended syntax: a recipe prefixed with `!` uses extended syntax (`!Aacute = A + acute`), otherwise simple syntax (`A+acute=Aacute`). - Turn **off** Use simple (FLS5) syntax to only use extended syntax (one glyph recipe per line).
dialog.generateglyphs.ligature: Generate Glyphs > Ligature; Generate Glyphs › Ligature can be used to **generate generate a single glyph which horizontally combines the glyphs** from the input selection. Eg: if your input selection was the text fön, FontLab will try to generate the glyph fodieresisn. To make your input selection, select the relevant glyphs in the Font window or type/paste/select them in the correct order in the Glyph window using the Text tool.
dialog.generateglyphs.precomposed: Generate Glyphs > Precomposed; Use Generate Glyphs › Precomposed to **generate a single glyph that overlays all glyphs from the input** you have selected in the Font window or Glyph window. The advance width of the new glyph will be equal to the width of the first glyph from the input selection, and this method will position the overlaid glyphs using anchors if they are present in the source glyphs.
dialog.generateglyphs.variants: Generate Glyphs > Variants; Using Generate Glyphs › Variants, you can **automatically generate variant glyphs** for each glyph that you have selected in the Font window or Glyph window as input. Enter the appropriate **Suffix** for the variants in the field on the left of the dialog, or use the dropdown to select from suffixes used for OpenType features. Eg: if your input selection is the text `fön` and you specify the suffix `ss01`, FontLab will try to generate the glyphs `f.ss01`, `odieresis.ss01` and `n.ss01`.
dialog.generateinstance: Generate Instance; The Generate Instance dialog is used to add new instances to the list of predefined instances of a variable font, to create a font master or a separate single-master font based on the selected position in the design space. In the top **list of predefined instances** select one of the instances that are already in the variable font. Use the **axes sliders** to pick a position in the design space. The current **instance preview** is shown below the list of sliders. **To add the current position to the list of predefined instances**, click the Add Instance button. **To create new font master using the current design position**, click the Add as Master button. **To create new single-master font using the current design position**, click the Create as Font button. New font will be opened in the separate Font window.
dialog.manageworkspaces: Workspaces; Use the Workspaces dialog to manage your workspaces. The dialog shows a list of all workspaces. **To rename a workspace**, 2×CLICK its name. **To activate a workspace**, select in the list and click Activate. **To delete a workspace**, select it in the list and click the minus-shaped Remove selected workspace. **To add an external workspace file**, click the Open workspace file button. **To export a workspace**, select it in the list and click the Save selected workspace to the file button.
dialog.overlayfonts: Overlay Fonts; Use the Overlay Fonts dialog to apply a different colors to every layer of one or more selected fonts to create chromatic fonts. The dialog has a local toolbar on the top, the list of source fonts used below that, current layer properties on the left and overlay preview at the bottom. Click **Add Family Members** to add any open fonts belonging to the same family as the fonts already in the sources in this dialog. Click the **Duplicate current font** button in the local toolbar to create a copy of the currently selected source in this dialog. Use the **Size** dropdown to change the size of the preview string. Click inside the overlay preview to modify the preview string. Select a font in the list of sources by clicking on it in the list. Now you can edit its properties on the left of the dialog: * **Font layer color** is shown as a standard color palette that includes the grayscale bar, black and white colors; and an additional popup palette with common colors below it. Use either to apply a color to the glyphs of the current layer. * Set the **Opacity** of the current layer using this slider. * You can also use the numeric **Color value** (RGB and hex) to set the color. * Enter the **X and Y offset** values in font units to move the layer. Use negative values to move left and/or down. * Use the **Scale factor** to reduce or enlarge glyph images. * Use the **Align** dropdown to align the glyph images to the left, right or center. * Enter the **Blur** value to soften edges of glyph images on the current layer. This effect can be used to imitate glyphs’ shadows. Use values below 10% for better results. Blurring by 50% and more may take several minutes. Select **Overlay to elements** to create the overlayed font with a single layer. FontLab will put two (or more) overlapping elements in each glyph. Select **Overlay to layers** to create the overlayed font with two (or more) layers. When you are satisfied with the overlay preview, click **OK** to create the new font.
dialog.preferences: Preferences; The **Preferences** dialog allows you to search, open, save, and reset preferences. Use the Search field on the top-right of the dialog **to search for any section of Preferences**. **To apply the changes you have made** in the dialog, click Apply then Ok. **To save your preferences**, use the hamburger menu on the left and click Save Preferences.... When you save your Preferences, all your settings are saved in an external file, including your password for your Digital Signature (DSIG) (if you saved that in your Preferences). **To open a preference file**, select Open Preferences... in the hamburger menu and a default Open dialog comes up. You can select a preferences file here. **To reset preferences** and go back to default settings, choose Reset to Defaults in the hamburger menu on the top-left of the dialog.
dialog.preferences.autohinting: Preferences > Autohinting; You can customize the following options for PostScript and TrueType Autohinting in Preferences › Autohinting: * **PostScript Autohinting** * If **Remove existing hints when autohinting a glyph** is on, and you run Tools › Autohint, FontLab will remove the existing glyph hints before calculating new hints. * If **Convert hints to links when autohinting** is on, and you run Tools › Autohint, hints will be converted to links. Links are “dynamic hints” — when you move nodes, the links will follow your design changes. * **TrueType Autohinting** * If **Generate triple hints** is active, FontLab will try to generate TrueType instructions that simulate PostScript triple hints for characters like ‘m’ where the distance between stems must be kept the same at all PPMs. * Use **Direct links to the center of the glyphs where possible** to customize the hinting direction. * If **Automatically interpolate positions of the cusp points** is on, FontLab will generate an Interpolate command that will link cusp points to one of the links. * If **Try to automatically generate middle delta instructions** is on, FontLab will attempt to generate small middle delta commands at the end of links that connect round parts of the glyph. * Use **Add link to the right sidebearing point** to generate a single, distance-rounded link that will go from the rightmost hinted point to the right sidebearing point. This feature guarantees at least one pixel distance between glyphs on all PPMs. * Select **Interpolate positions of the double links** if you would like FontLab to hint the first stem in a letter like B, which has overlapping stems, and then interpolate the position of the second stem using the interpolation command with the final point aligned to the grid. * In **Single link attachment precision** you can enter a value in this field so FontLab will have a threshold to decide when several points are located along a line. For precise fonts set this value to 1 or 0.
dialog.preferences.cousins: Preferences > Cousins; In Preferences › Cousins, you control the following: * Whether **Cousin glyphs are filled** if true fill is active, always or never. * Similarly, you can select whether the outline should be shown, or hidden or mask should be shown **If mask layer is active**. * Use the **Content appearance** dropdown to select the color for cousins and the accompanying **slider** to define opacity. * In SHIFT cousin glyphs++, you can decide whether to use metrics or SHIFT by a X/Y unit distance. Additionally, you can choose whether it will aligned to the left, right or center of the current glyph. * Enable **Double+click++ to edit the glyph** if you want to be able to switch between cousins that you’re editing. * The list shows which glyphs are defined as cousins. Each line shows one group with space-separated Unicode characters or glyph names. **To edit the list of cousins**, click within the blue box and add/delete glyphs.
dialog.preferences.curveconversion: Preferences > Curve Conversion; In Preferences › Curve Conversion, you can customize the following: * The **Curve conversion** tolerance options are used whenever you convert TrueType to PostScript or vice versa. Use the tolerance controls to define how close to the original should the result be. The less the value the more precise the conversion is. But note that FontLab may add points to make conversion more precise. * When **Add nodes every two TT off-curve points is active**, FontLab may add unnecessary nodes between off-curve points. If this option is off, unnecessary nodes won't be added.
dialog.preferences.defaulttexts: Preferences > Default Texts; In Preferences › Default Texts, you can edit the default texts for a new text block, sample used in the Preview panel and the sample used in Fonts panel. click any of the texts in the blue box to start editing.
dialog.preferences.digitalsignature: Preferences > Digital Signature; In Preferences › Digital Signature, you can control settings for digital signatures that can be included in the OpenType (TT or PS) fonts that you generate. If **Digitally sign exported OpenType fonts** is enabled, a DSIG table will be generated that includes a digital signature. You will also be able to control the following options: * In **Path to the certificate file (.spc or .cer)**, enter the location of the certificate file you have received from your certification authority. * In **Path to the private key file (.pvk)**, enter the location of the private key file you have received from your certification authority. * If **Request private key password every time** is selected, FontLab will ask you for the password for your private key every time you generate a font. * Or FontLab can remember the password for your private key in the preferences file, if you selet **Use the following password**. Note that when you save your Preferences to an external file, all your settings are saved, including the password for your Digital Signature. * Select **Generate the time stamp using the following URL** and enter the link to the service that is making time stamps to create time stamps. If empty, a time stamp will not be generated. * From the **Algorithm to build font data hash** dropdown, choose the algorithm, MD5 or SHA1, that will be used to build the font data hash. MD5 is the default. * In **Font vendor URL**, you can enter the the URL of the font vendor. This URL must match the one in the certificate file. If **Digitally sign exported OpenType fonts** disabled, a “dummy” empty DSIG table is generated and all options described above will be disabled as well.
dialog.preferences.distances: Preferences > Distances; In Preferences › Distances, you can tweak distances to customize the behavior of editing tools: * In the **Hit to node** field, you can enter the distance around a node where you can click to select it, instead of only clicking on it precisely. * In the **Hit to guidelines** field, you can enter the distance around a guideline where you can click to select it, instead of only clicking on it precisely. * In the **Join distance** field, you can define the distance within which two nodes will join when you move one to another. * If any objects in the Glyph window has “snap-to” turned on, moving a node will cause it to snap to those particular objects if the distance between the node and the object is not larger than **Snap distance** specified here. * Use **Min curve handle length** to define the minimum length of the handles to display them. To display handles whenever possible, set the value to 1. * Use **Outline arrow key moves** to define the distance (in font units) by which objects are moved when Arrow keys are used. * Use **Metrics arrow key moves** to define the distance (in font units) by which sidebearings are moved or kerning value is changed when Arrow keys are used. * Use **Outline ++Shift+arrow key moves** to define the distance by which objects are moved when ++Shift+Arrow keys are used. * Use **Metrics ++Shift+arrow key moves** to define the distance by which sidebearings are moved or kerning value is changed when ++Shift+Arrow keys are used. * In **Glyph window default zoom level**, you can define what zoom at 100% (View › Zoom 100% or Cmd+3) means. There are four options you can choose from.
dialog.preferences.editing: Preferences > Editing; You can customize how FontLab glyph editing looks and works in Preferences › Editing: * **Show scroll bars in the Glyph window** is on by default, and you should turn it off if you don’t need scroll bars in the Glyph Window and scroll with the mouse wheel or pan by pressing Space instead. * Enable **Pinch gesture zooms in the Glyph window** if you would like to zoom in the Glyph Window using pinching gestures. On Windows, if this option is enabled, you need to use Ctrl+Alt-mouse wheel to change the current glyph in the Glyph window. If it is turned off, Ctrl-mouse wheel needs to be used instead. * If alignment zones are not visible and **Highlight nodes on alignment zones** is enabled, and you move a point into an alignment zone, the zone will become visible again and the node will be highlighted. The highlighting is in a different style when the node is on the zone line versus when it is within the zone. * When **Pen and Pencil tools can change contour** is turned on drawing with the Pen tool and Pencil tool can add to existing contours. * When **Force snap to guides** is turned off, a node snaps to a guide only at idle, when you stop your mouse move, so you can move nodes smoothly. But when it is on, the node will snap when the mouse moves. * Turn on **Marquee selection selects nodes but not handles** if you would like handles inside the marquee selection rectangle to be selected whether or not the nodes on either side are selected. Note that even when this option is turned off, handles between selected nodes are selected. * Turn on **Clicking on outline selects segment** if you would like to select a segment by clicking on its outline. When this option is off, you can select a segment by SHIFT-clicking on it. * When **Pasting contour to another element preserves appearance** is on, copying and pasting contours from/to transformed elements is WYSIWYG: original contours are copied transformed to keep their look in the source element and so are pasted to the destination element. * When you DRAG any point on a curve segment (not the node) and **Curve handles have fixed direction when curve point is dragged** is off, the direction of the handles changes, so you can freely change the shape of the curve segment but you will also change the shape of neighboring curve segments if they connect via a smooth node. If this option is on, the direction of the handles stays fixed, so the change of the current curve segment will be limited, and neighboring segments stay intact. * If **Show cross** enabled, a crosshair cursor is shown whenever the user moves any nodes. * When **Holding CMD activates Contour tool** is turned on and some other tool is selected holding down CMD activates the Contour tool temporarily. This option is not available on Windows. * When **Always show anchor names** is turned on, anchor/pin names are always visible. Otherwise names become visible when the cursor approaches the anchor/pin. * When **Rapid tool remembers last state** is turned on, the Rapid tool remembers the type of added node (straight or smooth) and continues to add nodes of this type until you Ctrl+click++. * When **Live preview** is turned on and you edit a contour, you can see the “live” preview of the glyph in other windows or in the Preview panel while you DRAG the mouse. If turned off, the preview is updated at idle or when you release the mouse. This preview may be slow. * Use the options in **Glyph window property bar** to select where the Property bar will be placed in the GLyph window: at the top (default) or the bottom.
dialog.preferences.fontwindow: Preferences > Font Window; In Preferences › Font Window, you can customize how the Font Window looks and works: * In **Default Mode**, you can select whether you want to see new, imported or opened fonts in Encodings, Unicode, Codepage, Category, Script or Index mode. The default option is Encodings. * From the **Default encoding** dropdown, you can choose between a variety of OpenType or Type 1 encodings to filter glyphs in the Font window/Font Map panel. The default encoding is used for all new and imported fonts. * In **Default sorting**, which is set to Unicode by default, you can select your preferred mode of sorting in the Font window. * In **Cell caption properties**, you can select: 1. Whether **Cell caption** will be positioned at the top or bottom of the the cell. 2. A different **Caption font** or reset it to the original. 3. The **Caption size** to auto, small, medium or large. 4. Whether **Caption content is editable** is on or off. The option is off by default, and ff you turn it on you can edit the caption directly in the cells of the Font Window. 5. If the **Colorize numeric captions** is checked. If it is, cell captions with numeric information will be automatically colorized. Numeric captions are those showing glyph width, LSB, RSB, top or bottom of the glyph bounding box, number of elements, script or age. Cells in the List sidebar will also be colorized. * If **Open single glyph in existing Glyph window** is checked, then every time you open a single glyph from the Font window, it will be opened in the existing Glyph window replacing what is in the window at the time. * Use the **Background** dropdown to select the background color for cells with glyphs. This is white by default. * Use the **Highlight** dropdown to select the background color for cell captions. * Use the **Brightness** dropdown to select the color for the color flags. Color flags for cells are pale and desaturated by default. By modifying the transparency of the color flags using this slider, you can make them more or less bright. * Use the **Placeholder Font** option to select the font that will be used as template for empty glyph cells. click Reset to set the font back to the default. * Choose one of the options from **Absent glyphs** to select how absent glyphs will be shown in the Font window. * Check **Show grid lines** to see the lines that define the cell grid. * If **Show glyph metrics if cell is larger than “x” pixels** is selected then advance width is shown with a lighter background so left and right glyph sidebearings are visible. * **Show hinting icons** small hinting marks in the lower left corner of glyph cells that have hints. * **Show note icon** shows the note icon on glyphs that have notes. * If **Show note text if possible** is checked, FontLab will try to display the note text if the cell size is large enough to fit it. * In the **Unicode-name mapping** field, you can enter the path to the external file that contains glyph name to Unicode mapping rules. This operation requires the application to be restarted to be applied. * If **Interpret glyph name to generate Unicode index** is selected, FontLab will generate Unicode indices XXXX from names such as uniXXXX or uXXXX . * Use **Unicode index format** to select how Unicode numbers are shown: uppercase XXXX or lowercase xxxx. This doesn't affect exported fonts.
dialog.preferences.general: Preferences > General; In Preferences › General, you can make the following customizations: * There are three types of **Windows and tabs configuration** in FontLab that you can choose from: 1. All fonts and glyphs open in tabs. In this option, you can undock tabs to turn them into separate windows, and you can dock windows back. 2. Fonts open in windows, glyphs open in tabs 3. Fonts and glyphs open in windows. In this option, windows can still be docked manually to form tabs. * If **Font has at least one Font window** is active, a new Font Window appears every time you open, import or create new font, and closing the last Font window means closing the font. * If **Font Map and Fonts panels control fonts** is active and you open a font, a new Font Window doesn't appear. Instead you can control opened fonts in the Fonts panel and see glyph cells in the Font Map panel. Closing the last font window for the font won't close the font itself. It will remain open and seen in the Fonts panel. * When **Activate panels depending on type of activated objects** is active and you have multiple panels open in a tabbed panel group, selecting a particular object in the Glyph Window will bring the corresponding panel to the front. The panel is activated only if it was opened through Window › Panels. * **Close Glyph window sidebar after “x” minutes of inactivity** allows you to change the idle time after which the Glyph window sidebar is automatically closed. If you do not want it to close based on inactivity, uncheck this option. * **Open Sketchboard on startup** becomes available if you have chosen the second or third Windows and tabs configuration option. With this option, you can choose to open or not open the Sketchboard automatically on startup. In the first configuration, the Sketchboard always opens regardless of the setting. * **Autosave Sketchboard every x minutes** allows you to set the interval of saving the Sketcboard in minutes. FontLab saves the contents of the Sketchboard window in ~/Library/Application Support/FontLab/FontLab/sketchboard.vfc on macOS or in ~\AppData\Local\Fontlab\Fontlab VI\sketchboard.vfc on Windows on exit. * FontLab checks for updates and notifies you when an update is available. Updates are downloaded and installed only when you choose to download and install them. To not allow FontLab checking for updates every time it starts, turn off **Check for updates at startup**. **To manually check for the latest updates**, click the Check for updates now button or use the FontLab › Check for Updates menu. * Use the option in **Developer/Experimental Preferences** to do tests and identify possible issues: 1. **OpenGL** allows you to turn on OpenGL, a library for graphic computing. 2. **Preview keystrokes** shows every typed key on the screen, what can be used while doing a screen recording to report a problem.
dialog.preferences.glyphwindow: Preferences > Glyph Window; In Preferences › Glyph Window, you can make the following customizations: * You can select between five different options for **Node size**. * When the middle **Node style** option is selected (default), any node whose handles are aligned perfectly vertically or horizontally (or corner node whose adjacent line is almost vertical/horizontal) will be a darker solid color. Any node that does not meet such a test will be lighter and outlined. This helps identify points that are not quite where you intended, or are not quite proper extrema. * You can also select between three options for **Node color**. * Similarly, you can select how **Inactive nodes** are displayed — invisible, black or in color. * In **Open contours**, you can select whether they should rendered filled or unfilled. * Use the dropdown in **Show coordinates for current node and selected/all nodes** to select whether you want to see the coordinates of only selected nodes or all nodes when View › Show › Coordinates is on. If you choose the first option, coordinates of unselected nodes will only be shown when they are under the cursor. * You can set the size of text for coordinates of the current node using the field in **Font size for the current node coordinates**. * In **Show node name**, you can select whether the names of nodes (if they have a name) should be visible, invisible or along with the node’s coordinates. * If **High contrast rendering** is selected, items like metrics lines, guides, grid, etc. will be displayed with more contrast. * If **Glow contour selection** is selected, the selected contour gets an additional glowing effect (which is invisible on non-Retina screens). * Use the **Outline thickness** dropdown, you can choose how thick glyph outlines should be in the Glyph window — thin, normal or thick. * When **Pixel-perfect rendering** is turned on, the rendering of outlines, nodes, guides, sidebearings, font metrics and the crosshair will be rounded to full screen pixels, so all lines drawn in the Glyph window will be sharper, especially on non-Retina screens. * Use the **Quick measurement** dropdown to choose whether FontLab will show the stem thickness only on the stem (which is default), never, when the cursor is on the contour edge or everywhere, when it will measures not only stem thickness but also the distance between stems or stems and sidebearings. * Use the **Glyph fill transparency** slider to choose the opacity of filled outlines when you edit them. * Use the **Curvature** slider to customize the transparency for curvature. * Use the **Workspace b/g** dropdown to customize the background color for the Glyph window in the Text and Editing modes. * Use the **Mask b/g** dropdown to customize the background color for the Mask layer. * Use the **Mask color** dropdown to choose the color for outlines in the Mask layer. * Use the **Global mask color** dropdown to choose the color for outlines in the Global Mask.
dialog.preferences.grid: Preferences > Grid; In Preferences › Grid, you can customize the following: * In **Gridline distance**, you can define the distance between vertical and horizontal gridlines. * In **Slant angle**, you can define the angle for slanted vertical gridlines, which has to be within the -45˚+45˚ range. If you select **Follow the font’s italic angle**, an oblique font will be displayed with a slanted grid and sidebearings, and an upright font will be displayed with a vertical grid regardless of the slant angle that has been defined. * Use the **Gridlines color** dropdown let you to change the color of guidelines, and the use the **slider** to define their opacity. * Use the **Dots opacity** slider to change the opacity of gridlines intersections. * If **Round nodes, guides and anchors to grid points** is turned on, snapping to the grid becomes “strong” so that nodes, guides and anchors (but not handles) will snap to it immediately. If this setting is off, it will override the setting Show › Snap › Grid for nodes, anchors and guidelines.
dialog.preferences.openfonts: Preferences > Open Fonts; Options in Preferences › Open Fonts are applied to fonts when they are opened and imported in the application: * If **Detect tags for alignment zones** is on, FontLab will automatically assign tags to alignment zones when a font is imported. * If **Make friendly glyph names** is on, glyphs with names like "uniXXXX", "uXXXXX" and "afiiXXXXX" will be renamed to friendly names during import. * If **Change CID names to Unicode names when Unicode index in known** is on, which is default, FontLab names glyphs using its regular glyph naming heuristics when importing CID-keyed PostScript fonts. If you want glyphs named by CID number turn this option off. * If **Detect element references** is selected, FontLab will check glyphs in the font being opened or imported, and find identical elements. One of the found identical element will become the primary element, while others will be replaced by locked references to the primary one. If this option is unchecked, you can detect element references manually using Font › Detect Element References. * In the **Composite glyphs** section you can choose how composite glyphs in the font being opened or imported should be handled: 1. If you select **Convert to elements**, the components of the glyph will be converted to **element references** that can be manually unlocked and edited in place. 2. If you select **Keep as component elements**, the components will be references to **primary glyphs** that change when the primary is modified and cannot be manually edited in the glyph. * **OpenType features** controls the decompilation and compilation features: 1. If **Decompile binary features** is checked, the application will decompile any OpenType features in the font being imported, and present them as text that can be edited in the Features panel. 2. If **Compile feature definitions** is checked, FontLab will try to compile features imported from VFB and UFO file formats. This builds binary GPOS and GSUB tables (in memory), so they can be applied in the Glyph window. * In **Glyph contours**, if you check **Convert TrueType curves into PostScript curves**, the application will automatically convert the outlines on import. Curves are converted according to the settings set on the Curve Conversion section of the Preferences dialog. * FontLab can detect smart nodes automatically. In the **Detect smart nodes**, you can check whether you would like the application to detect **Servant nodes**, **Genius nodes** or both.
dialog.preferences.operations: Preferences > Operations; Preferences › Operations allows you to customize a number of different commands from Font, Glyph and Element menus: * Within **New glyph**, if **fill created glyphs with content when available** is turned on (which is the default), then when you 2×CLICK an empty glyph cell in the Font window or when you use the Font › Add Glyphs command, FontLab will create the glyph, and then it tries to generate the glyph as a composite or auto glyph in all font masters: the glyph layers are created and element references are added to the them. If create auto layers is possible is also checked, FontLab will generate the glyphs as auto glyphs, so their contents will automatically update when you add or modify primary glyphs later. * Use the **Power guides** dropdown to select whether element and glyph guides (which default), only element guides, element, glyph and font guides, element, glyph and font guides and zones or all guides, zones and font metrics should be used when you call the Glyph › Add Power Guides command. * **Precision** and **Smoothness** inside **Autotrace** can be used to tune up the autotracing algorithm which is called from the Element › Image › Autotrace and Element › Image › Separate and Trace operations. * If **Lock all element references except the primary element** is selected, when FontLab automatically creates element references, it will lock all references except the primary element. To keep all references unlocked, unselect this option. * If **recognize alphabetic characters during optical separation** is selected, FontLab will recognize characters and convert to outlines letters during Element › Image › Separate and Trace. Currently, this can be done in two languages: English and Russian, which can also be selected here.
dialog.preferences.pasteduplicate: Preferences > Paste & Duplicate; Preferences › Paste & Duplicate contains the following options: * **Duplicate offset**, set to 100/50 by default, controls the distance by which duplicated outlines are offset from original ones when they appear. * **Copy/Paste offse**, set to 0/0 by default, controls the distance by which copied outlines are offset when they are pasted. * Use **Scale artwork** to choose how artwork should be scaled and aligned. The options are Do not scale or align, Align only, Scale to UPM, align to descender, Scale to ascender - descender, Scale to caps height - baseline and Scale to caps height - descender.
dialog.preferences.savefonts: Preferences > Save Fonts; In Preferences › Save Fonts, you can make the following customizations: * Choose between a **Silent first save** or opening the **Save File dialog**: 1. If you choose the first option, **First save in specified folder with autogenerated file name** and you save a font for the first time, in will be saved in the First save folder specified below. 2. If **Ask for the font file name** is selected, the application will show you the Save File dialog where you can enter both the name and location for the file you are saving. * In **Save VFC and also**, you can select what font formats you want the files to be saved by default, apart from the proprietary binary format .VFC. The other formats available are UFO, VFB and VFJ. * In the **First save folder** field, you can enter the path to the location where new and imported fonts will be saved by default. * Use **Autosave opened fonts every _n_ minutes** to activate autosave and enter the time interval (in minutes) at which you want to save the font. Font will be saved in the Autosave folder within the FontLab user data folder. If Autosave was active and you have a system or program crash, you can open your last saved font here. * In the **Default rasterization PPM** field, you can add the value that will be used to set the resolution for rasterization if it has not been explicitly set. * Check **Add indentation and spaces while exporting FontLab JSON (.vfj) font file** if you would like the JSON to be indented. Bear in mind that this will increase the file size.
dialog.preferences.spacing: Preferences > Spacing; In Preferences › Spacing, you can control the following: * If **Align text to top-left when spacing mode is activated** is selected, in the Metrics, Kerning or Text mode the text block showing glyphs is aligned to the top and left of the window. You cannot pan the contents until you zoom-in close enough. * When **Double-clicking to glyph in Metrics mode opens it for editing** is selected, it emulates the FLS 5 behavior of opening glyphs for editing if they are double-clicked in the Metrics mode. * Turn off **Glyph can be dragged within the advance width in Metrics mode** to not allow dragging glyphs when editing metrics. Only sidebearing lines can be dragged if this option is off. * When **Inactive kerning pairs are editable** is turned on, all glyphs (except the first one) in a line can be dragged to change kerning. It is off by default so only the current and the following glyph can be dragged. * If **Automatically update linked metrics** is selected, linked metrics will be updated on the fly. This operation may be very slow. If this option is turned off, you must use the Font › Update metrics menu command to update linked metrics. * Use the **Metrics lines** dropdown to select a custom color for the vertical lines representing left and right sidebearings. * Use the **Metrics b/g** dropdown to customize the background color of the Glyph window when the Metrics tool is activated. * Use the **Kerning b/g** dropdown to customize the background color of the Glyph window when the Kerning tool is activated. * You can edit the tolerance values in **Auto kerning** to control automatic kerning creation in the Pairs and Phrases panel.
dialog.preferences.texts: Preferences > Texts; In Preferences › Texts, you can define the sample texts that appear in the Text dropdown in the Property bar of the Glyph window. The left pane lists all the titles, and on the right you can see the selected sample. - CLICK a text title to see the sample on the right. The samples are editable. - 2×CLICK a title to edit it. - Use + to add a new sample. - Use - to remove a selected title.
dialog.preferences.variations: Preferences > Variations; In Preferences › Variations, you can make the following customizations: * Turn on **Preview master color** to see either a bar on top of the Glyph window in the color selected for the master you are currently editing; or the same color as background. Under this section, you can choose between the **Bar** and **Background**, define the thickness of the bar and the brightness of the background (the color of both is defined in the Layers & Masters panel). * Turn off **Show #instance layer** to hide the #instance layer containing interpolation results. * The settings in **Synchronize in matching masters** allow you to perform an editing action on the current master and have the same action “replayed” on all other masters that match the current master. As a result, your editing actions affect all compatible masters at once. The setting are: * If **Insert node** is selected, it keeps masters compatible when you add a node to a contour on one of the masters. The new interpolated node is added on the corresponding contour in other masters automatically. But if you add a new contour, masters will lose their compatibility. * **Rename node**, if selected, renames nodes across masters. * If **Remove node** is selected, it keeps masters compatible when you delete a node on one of the masters. The corresponding node is deleted in other masters automatically. If you delete a contour, the corresponding contour is removed on other masters as well. * **Add and rename guide**, if selected, adds a guide on all matching masters whenever you add a guide in the current master. If you rename a guide in one master, the guides with the same old name on other matching masters will get the same new name. * **Add hint**, if selected, allows you to add a hint on all matching masters. * If **Add or remove anchor** is selected, it allows you to add an anchor on all matching masters in the same position, and removes anchors from all matching masters that have the same name as the anchor you’re removing from the current master.
dialog.profiles: Profiles; In the Profiles dialog, you can activate/deactive default profiles and create/remove custom ones. A profile is a group of settings for exporting fonts, in a particular format. On the left of the dialog are names of profiles. FontLab has the following default profiles: OpenType TT (.ttf), OpenType PS (.otf), FontLab (.vfc), FontLab JSON (.vfj), UFO Package (.ufo), FontLab Classic (.vfb), PostScript Type 1 (.pfb), DesignSpace+UFO (.designspace), OpenType Variations (.ttf), Web TT (.ttf, .eot, .woff) and Web PS (.woff2, .woff). These profiles are not editable. **To see the details of a profile**, select it in the list on the left. **To activate a profile, i.e. see it in the Export Font As dialog**, select the checkbox to the left of the profile name in the list. If the checkbox is blue, the profile is activated. **To deactivate a profile, i.e. remove it from the Export Font as dialog**, unselect the checkbox to the left of the profile name in the list. **To add a new profile**, select a profile in the list and press the plus-shaped Add profile button. This will create a duplicate of the selected profile that you can now edit. In a custom profile, you can edit the following options: * **Parameter** * In **Profile name**, enter the name of the profile as it appears in the Export Font dialog. * In **Profile subfolder**, enter the name for the folder where exported fonts appear if the Profile option in the Export Font dialog is turned on. * **Format Settings** * Use the **Format** dropdown to select the general font file format * Select **Use legacy format version** if you would like FontLab to do that. * **Outlines** * Use the **Curve Conversion** dropdown to choose whether all curves should be converted to PostScript or TrueType or be lest as they are. Note that curves will be converted if the particular format requires it. * In the **Conversion tolerance** dropdown you can choose whether to keep the tolerance for conversion the same as has been specified in Preferences, or a different value depending on the size of the file. * Select **Correct contour direction** if you would like FontLab to fix the contour direction according to specification requirements. * Select **Remove overlaps** if you would like FontLab to merge overlapping parts of contours. This is needed for traditional non-variable final font formats but is not needed for development or variable formats. * Turn on **Nodes at X extremes** to place nodes at horizontal extreme coordinates. * Turn on **Nodes at Y extremes** to place nodes at vertical extreme coordinates. * Select **Clean Up** to remove unnecessary nodes. * Use the **Round Coordinates to UPM grid** dropdown to choose how rounding of the contour points to the integer grid is performed. Keep fractional nodes and handles is the default, but rounding is always performed for TTF and VFB. * Select **Open contours** if you would like open contours to be exported. * **Compression** * Use the **TTF: use composites** dropdown to choose how TrueType outlines will be compressed by defining how composite and auto glyphs will be exported. * Select **OTF: use subroutines** to use CFF subroutine compression to reduce file size of OTF fonts. Checking this option leads to lossless compression, but export may be slow in large fonts or fonts will many repeating elements. * Select **UFO: compress as .ufoz** to save UFO files in compressed form (.ufoz). Note that this format may not be compatible with other 3rd aprty apps. * **Hinting** * Turn on **Use Hinting** to export hints and generate a hinted font. This option should be off for very complex or rough designs. * Use the **Autohint** dropdown to select what glyphs should be autohinted: none, unhinted ones or all. * Select **Use x-direction hints** to exported vertical hints. * Select **Recalc zones** to automatically recalculate safe top and bottom zones. If this option us turned off, existing zones are used. * Select **Recalc stems** to automatically recalculate standard stems.
