If this option is turned off, existing defined stems are used. * **TrueType Hinting** * Use the **TrueType hinter** dropdown to choose the hinting method: the one specified in FontInfo, FontLab TTH that allows manual hinting, or TTF Autohint that always autohints the font. * Select **Use existing visual TTH commands** if you would like FontLab to compile visual hints (if defined) into low-level TT hinting instructions (FontLab TTH only). * Select **Use imported TrueType native hinting** if you would like FontLab to write the imported low-level TT hinting instructions (FontLab TTH only). * Select **Rebuild PS hints** if you would like PostScript hints to be automatically rebuilt before running FontLab TTH (FontLab TTH only). * **Glyph Organization** * Turn on **Add required glyphs** to add missing required glyphs: .notdef, NULL, CR, space. * Select **Sort glyphs in optimal order** to apply the glyph ordering (physically reorders glyphs in the font) which is optimal for the Format. * Use the **Glyph names** dropdown to select how glyph names are included in the font. * **Features and Kerning** * Use the **Export OpenType features** dropdown to choose if feature code should be compiled only if binary is not present, or of it should be always compiled, or never. * Use the **OpenType kerning** dropdown to choose if the kern feature is created, if it should export the existing kern feature, or if it should be exported without OT kern. * Use the **OpenType mark attachment** dropdown to choose if mark and mkmk features are created, the existing ones are exported, or if it should be exported without the features. * Turn on **Export legacy TrueType kerning** to export the plain 'kern' table, which is used in old applications. FontLab will expand class kerning to build plain pairs. * In the **Max legacy TrueType kerning pairs** field, enter the number of pairs in kern table that will be exported; extra pairs will be ignored. * **Export Web font files** * Turn on **WOFF2: modern browsers** to export WOFF2 font file. * Turn on **WOFF: most browsers** to export WOFF font file. * Turn on **EOT: for IE (TT-only)** to export Microsoft EOT font file. * **Export color font files** * Select **OpenType+SVG: Adobe/Mozilla** to export color OpenType+SVG font. * Select **OpenType+COLR: Windows** to export color OpenType font with COLR+CPAL tables. * Select **OpenType+sbix: macOS & iOS** to export OpenType font with Apple's sbix bitmap table. * Select **OpenType+CBDT: Android** to export OpenType font with CBDT bitmap table.
dialog.renameglyph: Rename Glyph; The Rename Glyph dialog can be used to rename the current glyph. The dialog shows the current name and unicode of the glyph, followed by the following options: * To change a glyph’s name enter a new one in the **New name** field. If this glyph has a properly assigned Unicode codepoint and you want to find the name mapped to that index in FontLab database press the **Update** button to the right of the field. * Use the **New Unicode** field to enter the glyph’s new Unicode codepoint(s). You may enter more than one Unicode codepoint separated by a space: this will cause the glyph to be associated with multiple codepoints. Use the **Update** button to find the Unicode codepoint(s) mapped to a glyph’s name in FontLab’s database. * If the option **Replace existing glyphs with the same name** is not checked, and you enter a name that is already assigned to one of the font’s glyphs, the Rename button will be disabled and you will not be able to assign that name. Switch the option on to allow FontLab to replace glyphs. * Select **Keep replaced glyphs with the new name** to keep a copy of the replaced glyph under a new name. * Select **Rename glyph in OT features and classes** to automatically change the glyph name in OpenType classes that contain the glyph name, and in OpenType feature text. * Select **Rename glyph in kerning pairs and classes** to automatically change the glyph name in kerning classes that contain the glyph being renamed and in the 'kern' feature text. Press the **Rename** button to assign a new name to the glyph. If you want to rename more glyphs in sequence, instead press the **Rename Next Glyph** button. A new name will be assigned to the current glyph (as if you had pressed the OK button) and data from the next glyph will appear for editing.
font.focus: Font window; The Font window enables you to view the entire glyph set as a table of cells, sort and filter them, and select one or multiple glyphs to change. In the property bar, choose what’s shown as the cell captions and how the glyph cells are sorted. Change the cell size in the bottom status bar. Use the colorful rectangles to flag glyphs so you can tell what’s “done” or “important”. Add a filter to focus on a particular subset of your glyphs. The glyphs that match the filter will be shown first, and their cell captions will be yellow. To add a filter, type into the Search box, use the History sidebar or use the View mode dropdown. Some filters are “strict”: they only show the glyphs that match and exist in your font. Other filters are “loose”: they show existing glyphs (white cell background) and empty glyph cells for glyphs that don’t yet exist but would match the filter (gray cell background). Select one or more empty glyph cells and 2×CLICK to create these glyphs. Select one or more existing glyphs and 2×CLICK or click any tool in the Toolbar to open these glyphs in a Glyph window. Select one or more existing glyphs and use items from the Glyph, Element, Contour or Tools menus to perform changes on the current layer of the selected glyphs. Use Tools › Actions to perform changes on all layers. DRAG-DROP cells when the View mode and Sort are both **Index** to manually rearrange the glyph order. DRAG-DROP cells in other modes onto empty glyph cells to assign new names and Unicodes, and onto existing glyphs to replace them. The List sidebar shows more details about each glyph in a multi-column text view. Change the Cell caption dropdown to show different columns; click the column headers to sort. MCMD­·CLICK WCTRL­·CLICK the tab title or on the icon left of the Family name in the Font window title bar to see the file path for your font.
glyph.focus: Glyph window; Draw, edit, space, kern and preview glyphs in the Glyph window. To open a Glyph window, 2×CLICK any existing glyph cell in the Font window or Font Map panel, or select one or more glyphs and tap ↩. If Preferences › General › Fonts and glyphs open in windows is off, a new tab with the glyph(s) will be opened. Otherwise the glyph(s) will opened in a new separate window.
panel.anchorspins: Anchors and Pins panel; See and manage anchors and pins of the current glyph layer with the **Anchors and Pins panel**. Use the Anchors/Pins toggle at the top left of the panel to view either the **anchors** that position and attach glyphs together, or **pins** that position and attach elements. **To see the properties of an anchor or pin**, click it in the list, or in the glyph window. The panel will display its **name**, **position** and **location expression** below the list. Use the expression field to position the anchor or pin dynamically in relation to other named guides, anchors and pins. **To activate/deactivate an anchor or pin**, click the icon before its name in the list (diamond-shaped for anchors, circular for pins). If the icon is filled, it means the anchor or pin is activated; if it is only an outline, it means deactivated. To activate all anchors or pins in the list, click the check-mark button in the panel header. To deactivate everything in the list, click the cross-mark button. **To view the list of glyphs or elements that are linked to the selected anchor or pin**, select it and click the grid-shaped Show linked glyphs or elements button. If the Font window is active, 2×CLICK the glyph in the list selects this glyph cell in the font. If the Glyph window is active, 2×CLICK the glyph in the list adds this glyph to the window for edit. **To remove an anchor or pin**, select it in the list and click the – button at the panel's bottom.
panel.brush: Brush panel; The **Brush panel** allows you to change the size and shape of the **Brush tool**, and apply the brush to glyphs or elements. **To set the brush angle**, DRAG the blue arrowhead in the illustration of the brush tip, or manually edit the angle value (in degrees). **To set the brush roundness**, DRAG the blue dot in the illustration of the brush tip. Move the dot to the left to make the brush less round, and to the right to make it rounder. You can also enter a specific number from 0 (no rounding) to 100 (completely circular) manually. **To set the brush size**, use the slider, or manually enter a value between 0 to 300, or choose a predefined size from the dropdown menu. **To define the stroke shape**, use the blue control points on the horizontal edge of the illustration of the stroke. Each control point can be dragged between a value of 0 to 100%, which can also be entered manually. **To define the shape of the stroke’s beginning or end cap**, click the blue control point on the respective end of the stroke shape illustration. The default setting is a round cap, which is represented by a filled blue circle, and creates a stroke with semicircular ends. Clicking on the circle once will create a butt cap, i.e. a stroke with squared ends. This is represented by a square with a blue outline. Clicking on it one more time will convert it to a projected cap, i.e with squared ends that extend half the line width beyond the end of the stroke. This is represented by a half-filled blue square. **To choose a predefined brush**, select it in the list of predefined brushes. **To add a new brush to the list**, edit the brush’s size and shape using the option described above, and then click the + button below the list. **To delete a brush**, select it and click - button below the list. Finally, use the harmburger menu **to save the whole list** of brushes to an external file, or **load them from an external file** or **reset the list** to factory defaults. **To apply a Power Brush filter to the current glyph or glyph cells selected in the Font window**, click Set. **To remove the Power Brush filter**, click Remove. **To convert the Power Brush filter effect to regular contours**, click Expand.
panel.classes: Classes panel; The **Classes panel** helps you define, view and edit the OpenType and kerning classes in your font. **To select viewing modes**, use the Preview area, Table area and List sidebar buttons at the far right of the local toolbar. The panel has the following viewing modes: 1. The **Preview** area shows the preview of all glyphs included in the selected class(es). **To preview kerning classes in this mode**, select the first (left) kerning class and then CMD­·CLICK to select the second (right) kerning class, or select the same classes in the Kerning panel. 2. The **Table area** shows glyphs belonging to the selected class(es) as cells along with their names. 3. The **List sidebar** shows glyphs belonging to the selected class(es) along with information about them, as a list of either glyph names, Unicode or the character (which can be changed using the menu under the List sidebar). Information includes Name, Unicode, LSB, Width, RSB and OT Class, and the list can be sorted based on any of these. By default, all classes are shown in this panel. **To filter which classes or tags are shown**, click the Class type dropdown at the left of the local toolbar. In this menu, you can choose between all classes, first kerning classes, second kerning classes, first and second kerning classes, OpenType classes, tags and virtual tags. **To find a particular class**, type its name in the Filter field. **To import classes from another open font (or font master)**, select the Import submenu in the panel's local menu, accessed via the hamburger icon. This submenu contains names of all opened fonts/masters. Selecting one of the fonts/masters opens a dialog box, where you can choose what classes will be imported and how existing classes will be dealt with. **To define a new tag or class**, click the plus-shaped Add class button below the list of classes in the sidebar. Clicking on this button brings up a dropdown menu where you can select whether you want to add a 1st Kerning Class, 2nd Kerning Class, OpenType Class or Tag. Select the option you need. Once you do that, a new class or tag with a default name will be created, with the glyphs selected in the Font Window as its members. **To rename a class or tag**, select it in the list, enter a new name in the Name field in the local toolbar of the panel and click anywhere to apply the change. **To add glyphs to a class or tag**, enter glyph names to the text field under the Table area; or select glyphs in the Font Window and press the plus-shaped Add glyphs to class button under the view area; or DRAG-DROP glyphs from the Font window to the Table area or List sidebar. **To sort classes by their type and names**, click the Class column title in the list of classes. OpenType classes sorted by their names go first in the list, then 1st classes and finally 2nd classes. **To sort classes by the number of members**, click the Size column title in the list of classes. **To manually reorder classes**, select them and DRAG-DROP lower or higher in the list. **To merge two or more classes**, select them in the list sidebar, click the Select Glyphs button, and then on the plus-shaped Add glyphs to class button under the Preview/Table Area. The selected glyphs will be added to the first class that you’ve selected, and — if this was a kerning class — they will be removed from the other kerning classes of the same type. **To assign a color mark to class**, select it in the list and use the color list and dropdown in the local toolbar. **To remove a class or tag group**, select it in the list sidebar and click the minus-shaped Remove selected classes button. **To remove all classes**, click the local menu button and choose Remove All Classes. This will remove classes but leave the tags intact. **To automatically generate kerning classes**, click the local menu button and choose Generate Kerning Classes. **To remove any glyphs from selected classes that are not present in the font**, choose Clean Up Selected Classes in the local menu. **To select glyph cells in the Font window belonging to the selected class**, click the Select glyphs rectangle-shaped button. **To delete a glyph**, select it in the list sidebar and press Delete on your keyboard.
panel.color: Color panel; The **Color panel** is a color picker for selecting and applying colors to contours and their fills. Colors are applied to entire Elements, which means that contours in the same element cannot have different colors. However, different Element References can be colored differently. The colors you apply will be maintained if you generate fonts in a format that supports color. To save and remember predefined colors, use the **Swatches Panel** instead. The Color panel can be used in three different interface modes – wheel panel, sliders panel and box panel. **To select the interface mode of your choice**, use the toggle in the panel header. No matter which mode you choose, the panel will show the details of the selected color at the bottom of the panel in RGB, HSL, hexadecimal or Lab format depending on what you choose in that dropdown. **To change a contour color**, click the unfilled circle in the top left corner, select a color and click Apply. **To change a fill color**, click the filled circle, select a color and click Apply. Hold ALT and click Apply to apply the color to the current layer of all selected glyphs in a Font window. panel.elements: Elements panel; The **Elements panel** helps you manage all the Elements in the current glyph. The list shows the basic properties of each element: name, position in the glyph, whether they are locked or unlocked, number of references the element has and its colour(s). **To see and edit all properties of elements**, click the Show element properties button in the panel header. The **Element name** can be modified by typing a new name in the field and pressing Return. **To create a new glyph with a selected element as a reference**, first select an element, type a name in the Name field and click the Create glyph button. **Element transformations** are attributes of the selected element or element reference. They include position/shift, scale, flip, rotate, slant, body color, stroke width, color and opacity. Different element transformations can be applied to different references of the same element. The **Position** of the selected element is shown as X and Y co-ordinates. **To SHIFT the element**, modify these values and press Return. **To set the position to 0,0**, click the Reset button. **To center the element between glyph sidebearings**, click the Center in metrics button. The **Scale** of the selected element is shown as its width and height. **To scale an element**, modify the values for its width and height. Values above 100% will make it larger, and below 100% will make it smaller. **To scale an element proportionally**, enter the same value for its width and height. **To revert the element to its original size**, click the Reset button. Use the Flip horizontally and/or Flip vertically buttons to **Flip** the selected element. Enter values in degrees to the **Rotate** or **Slant** fields to transform the selected element by that angle. The point of origin is the bottom left. **To bring the element back to its original form**, use the Reset button. Use **Body Color** to set the fill color of a contour element. Color information is always preserved in VFCs, and also in exported fonts if the export format supports color. Changing the body color of a sticker element changes its background color. Use **Stroke width and color** to add a stroke of your chosen width and color to the selected contour element. Stroke color is always preserved in VFCs, and also in exported fonts if the export format supports color. Changing the stroke color of a sticker element changes its arrow and text color. Modify the **Opacity** of the selected element either with the slider or by entering a value between 0 (completely transparent) and 100 (completely opaque) in the input field. Opacity changes affect both body color and stroke of the element. You can also add **Element notes** in the form of text. Each element note is shared by all references to the element. **To see all references of the selected element**, click the Show element references button in the panel header. All glyphs referencing the selected element will be shown in a grid at the bottom of the panel. **To change the size of the grid cells**, use the Smaller cells or Bigger cells buttons above the grid. 2×CLICK (or Cmd+double-click++) on any glyphs in the grid **to add them to the Glyph window for editing**. Use the Set Metrics button **to copy metrics from the base glyph to the selected glyphs containing it as reference**. **To delete an element**, select it and press the - button at the bottom-left of the panel. **To make more space for the list of elements**, click the downward arrow shaped Contract properties button. This will hide the color and notes sections.
panel.features: Features panel; Use the **Features panel** helps you view, manage and edit the OpenType feature definitions in your font. You write feature definitions in the industry-standard Adobe FEA syntax. Features are defined per font. When you export OpenType fonts, the app preprocesses and **compiles** the feature definition code. When FontLab finds special _auto code lines_ (the opening line starts with `#>`, the closing line starts with `#<`), the app automatically generates code between the lines depending on the `#> keyword` (see below): ``` #> keyword #< keyword ``` FontLab replaces the auto code liens with an _auto code block_ and updates it automatically. To prevent the auto code block from updating, change `#>` to `#/>`. #### Managing features **To add a new feature**, click + in the bottom-left corner. This lists common features that are not yet defined in your font. Choose a feature marked with ☆ to add the feature and to autogenerate its code. Choose a feature without a mark to add placeholder code that you can edit. Choose Empty feature, then enter the feature tag and press ↩ to add placeholder code for an unlisted feature. Then edit the placeholder code. **To add all features that can be autogenerated**, choose ☰ › Add Auto Features. Each feature block must start with `feature xxxx {` and must end with `} xxxx;`, where `xxxx` is the 4-letter feature tag. Inside, you can define named lookup definition blocks that start with `lookup nnnnn {` and end with `} nnnnn;`, where `nnnnn` is a lookup name (any length, plain English letters and digits, no spaces). In later feature definitions, you can refer to them with `lookup nnnnn;`. If you don’t define a named lookup block, the whole feature block defines a name-less lookup. Inside the lookup block (or feature block), you can specify substitution rules (with the `sub` keyword) or positioning rules (with the `pos` keyword). **To autogenerate the auto code** for existing features marked with ☆, select them and CLICK the Autogenerate code for selected features button. This replaces the manual code with an auto code block inserted between the auto code lines `#> feature` and `#< feature`, and changes the indicator to ★. To combine manual and auto code, cut your code first, click the button, then paste after the `#< feature` closing line. Put the `#> feature` auto code block inside a named lookup block inside a `feature` block to re-use the auto code in other features. **To update auto code in auto features** marked with ★, select the features and CLICK the Update selected auto features button. ALT­·CLICK to update all auto features. The app updates all `#> feature` auto code blocks. It does not replace manual code or the disabled auto code block that starts with `#/>`. **To always update all auto features before compilation or export**, turn on ☰ › Update on Compile (useful when you keep adding glyphs to your font). Turn this off to only update manually when you click or ALT-click Update selected auto features (faster, useful if your glyph set is stable). **To reorder feature definitions** (which influences the order in which lookups are applied when the end-user turns on multiple features), DRAG-DROP the feature tags in the list. **To remove one or more features**, select them in the list, then click -. **To remove all features, including compiled binary data**, choose the ☰ › Remove All Features. **To import feature definitions from an external file**, choose ☰ › Import Features... and choose a `.fea`, `.vfc`, `vfj`, `vfb`, `.ufo` or `.txt` file. **To import features from another font that is currently open**, choose ☰ › Copy Features From and select the source font. **To export features to a `.fea` file or to a VOLT project `.vtp` file**, choose ☰ › Export Features. #### Editing and testing features **To edit a feature definition**, click its tag on the list and edit the definition in the features editor. Click FEATURES to see all feature definitions at once, as well as any code that is written after the last feature definition. **To edit languagesystems and standalone lookups**, click PREFIX. Prefix contains `languagesystem ssss LLL` definitions, which define the scripts (`ssss` 4-letter tags) and languages (`LLL` 3- or 4-letter language tags or `dflt`) in which all features are registered. The `#> languagesystem` auto code block will auto-update the definitions as you add glyphs. For script- and language-specific feature code, use `script ssss` and `language LLL` keywords inside the feature blocks. You can also place standalone named `lookup` definition blocks in the Prefix, and refer to them in feature blocks. **To use classes or tags** defined in the Classes panel as named classes in your feature code, inside the Prefix add the auto code block `#> otclasses` for OpenType classes, `#> kernclasses` for kerning classes, `#> tags` for tags manually assigned to glyphs. Or enable checkboxes in ☰ › Include Classes and add an auto code block `#> classes` in Prefix. **To use virtual tags** that FontLab automatically assigns to glyphs based on various criteria, include them in the menu or add a `#> vtags` auto code block in Prefix. Then use feature classes like `@ALL` (all glyphs except `.notdef`), `@blank` (whitespace), `@noblank` (have content), `@composite` (have components), `@noncomposite` (don’t have components), `@references` (component sources), `@uc` (uppercase), `@lc` (lowercase), `@fig` (numerals), `@latn` (4-letter script code). **To use virtual GDEF tags**, select all or some glyphs in Font window, click Glyph panel › Auto Glyph Definition class to classify them, add a `#> vtags` auto code block, then use the feature classes `@otsimp` (base glyphs), `@otmark` (marks), `@otliga` (ligatures), `@otcomp` (components), `@otnone` (other). **To test features** in the Glyph window, CLICK the Compile features button or press CTRL­·↩, then turn on Features in the Glyph window sidebar or in Text mode property bar. If Output panel reports **warnings**, features will compile, but you may want to check them. If it reports **errors**, you must fix them to export the font with features. The feature editor highlights the 1st error, though the error may actually occur earlier in the code, so check the previous feature definition as well. **To insert a glyph** into the feature editor, type its name as used in the font, or tap / to bring up the Quick Find popup. There, type a partial glyph name, Unicode character or a glyph name synonym, choose the glyph using ←↑↓→ and press ↩ to insert the correct glyph name. In the Quick Find popup, press ESC to type `/` into the feature editor, or press / to type `slash`. **To search within the feature definitions**, press MCMD­·F WCTRL­·F to jump to the search field, enter the name of a feature, lookup, glyph or class. Keep tapping ↩ or clicking the Search button until you find the right match. #### Positioning features Features are defined per font. When you export OpenType masters or instances, the app generates the `kern` feature from interpolated kerning, and generates the `mark` & `mkmk` features from interpolated anchors depending on the Features and Kerning section of the export profile. When you export variable OpenType fonts, the app uses the kerning classes of the main master and matches the kerning of the other master (losslessly converts the existing kerning into kerning based the main master’s kerning classes). **To manually edit the `kern` feature**, choose ☰ › Create [kern] Feature. This adds a `kern` feature to the panel based on **current master’s** kerning and classes. **To manually edit the `mark` and `mkmk` features**, choose ☰ › Create [mark] and [mkmk] Feature. This adds a `mark` and `mkmk` features to the panel based on **current master’s** anchors. This code will be used for **all masters** and instances. **To add manual code to autogenerated `kern` feature**, create it in ☰, then click Autogenerate code for selected features. In Font Info › Parameters, add a new parameter (e.g. `Lquote`) and set a value. If you have multiple masters, click Match Parameters and adjust the value in each master. At the end of the `kern` code, below `#< feature`, write your manual code that can refer to Font Info parameters, e.g. `pos L quoteright' @ALL ${Lquote};`. Turn on ☰ › Update on Compile to always update the auto code on compile and export. Use the same technique for `mark`/`mkmk`. and use Font Info `${parameters}` in other `cpsp` and other positioning features.
panel.fontaudit: FontAudit panel; The **FontAudit panel** lists the FontAudit problems for the current glyph and layer. The list shows the name of the problem, the x,y coordinate the problem exists, and has a Fix button that tries to fix the problem. Turn on View › Show › FontAudit (MSHIFT­·CMD­·F WSHIFT­·CTRL­·F) to **visualize** the problems in the Glyph window using colorful FontAudit markers. CLICK in the list **to highlight the problem marker in the Glyph window**. **To see a description** of the problem, hold F1 over a problem in the panel list, or click a problem marker in the window (which opens a FontAudit problem popup). **To try to fix an individual FontAudit problem**, click the Fix button in the popup at the right side of the list entry. Fixing may not be successful and may produce other problems. **To try to fix all the FontAudit problems in the current glyph layer**, click Fix All in the popup or in the panel footer. **To change which tests are run by FontAudit**, use the panel ++gear-button== or Preferences › FontAudit.
panel.fontinfo: Font Info panel; The **Font Info panel** is a shorter, non-modal alternative to the Font Info dialog, showing the most important font properties. Because it does not show as much information, it is not a replacement for the Font Info dialog—which can be opened by clicking on the i button in the right top corner of the Font Info panel. Use the Font Info/Parameters toggle on the top-left panel **to choose what information you want to see in the panel**. The Font Info section shows the following: - The **Typographic family name** (TFN or just “Family” or “Family Name”) is the name under which all fonts from one family are grouped in the font menu of a modern application. The Typographic family name must be identical in all fonts that need to appear as one family in the font menu of modern applications. The length of the Typographic family name should be no more than 31 characters. We recommend you use only uppercase and lowercase English letters, spaces and numerals. - The **Typographic style name** (TSN or just “Style”) is the name under which a specific font within a family appears in the font menu of modern applications. It is sometimes called “Preferred style name”. - The **Attributes** of a font or master describe its typographic properties. They are declared by the font vendor. The three key attributes are: Weight, Width and Slope and are shown in that order in the panel. There is also Other for custom attributes. - The **Units Per eM (UPM)** is the basis of all font dimensions. The UPM is the number of font units that the coordinate grid on which the glyphs are drawn and to which all font dimensions relate, including the font height. **To change the UPM**, click Change. This will bring up a dialog where you can enter the new UPM value and choose whether you would like to only update the UPM, or also scale the glyphs and metrics to the new value. - **Ascender** shows the position of the font’s ascender line. - **Descender** shows the position of the font’s descender line. - **Line Gap** shows the typographically correct line gap value (distance between bottom line of the upper line of text and top line of the lower line of text). - **Caps Height** shows the height of the font’s uppercase characters. - **x-Height** shows the height of the lowercase characters. - **Italic Angles** shows the actual italic or oblique angle for the font. The italic angle is measured in the counterclockwise direction, but FontLab shows it positive here. - **Caret Offset** is the amount by which a slanted highlight on a glyph needs to be shifted to produce the best appearance. Non-slanted fonts should have a setting of zero. - **Curve Tension** is a measure of how much a curve deviates from a straight line between two points, from zero to 100%. - **Vertical and Horizontal Stems** is the place to define PS standard stems used in font hinting procedures. **To automatically generate any of the information in this section**, click the Auto button next to the appropriate field. The Parameters section lists **pre-defined variables** (ascender, descender, xheight and capsheight), **font guidelines** and **user-defined parameters** that can be used in expressions. **To define a new parameter**, click the plus-shaped Add parameter button, name the variable and DRAG the slider to define its value. **To remove an existing parameter**, select it in the list and click the minus-shaped Remove parameter button. **To modify the value of a parameter or variable**, enter the new value in the input area, use the number steppers or the slider. Note that changing the value of a pre-defined variable will change your font’s dimensions.
panel.fontmap: Font Map panel; The **Font Map panel** is the functional replacement for the Font Window in FontLab. It looks like the Font Window, and if several fonts are open in FontLab, it shows the contents of the currently selected font. To take advantage of the Font Map panel, switch off the Close font when its Font window is closed option in **Preferences > General**, and open the **Fonts panel** Window › Panels › Fonts. The alternative way to open the Font Map panel is to 2×CLICK the local toolbar of the Glyph window. **To see an open font in the Font Map panel**, select it in the Fonts panel. **To preview several fonts together in the Font Map panel**, select them in the Fonts panel. **To add the same color flag to a set of glyphs in more than one font**, select them in the Fonts panel, and change their color flag. Cells of the selected fonts will get the same color flag.
panel.fonts: Fonts panel; The **Fonts panel** shows all open fonts grouped by families. If you have several fonts open, **use this panel to select which font’s contents will be shown in other panels**, such as the Preview, Font Map and Font Info. **To open fonts using the Fonts panel**, DRAG-DROP them from a folder to the panel. **To close fonts using the Fonts panel**, select the font(s) and click the – button in the panel’s footer. **To duplicate a font**, select it in the Fonts panel and click the Duplicate button in the footer. The duplicate font will appear in the Fonts panel as a member of the same family. **To change the sort order for your fonts**, click the hamburger button and select Alphabetically or Typographically.
panel.gallery: Gallery panel; The **Gallery panel** is the container of all **named** Elements (linked and unlinked) in your font. Elements are listed alphabetically in the panel, and you can use the **Filter** field to find an element by its name. Along with a preview of the element, each grid cell shows the number of references and the element name is shown at the bottom-left of the panel. **To change the size of the grid cells**, use the Smaller cells or Bigger cells buttons. **To place an element from the Gallery panel into the current glyph**, DRAG and drop it from the panel into the Glyph window, or select the Element in the panel and click Place. The element will be inserted as a linked reference. **To place an element from the Gallery panel into a single glyph in the Font window**, DRAG and drop the element to the glyph cell of your choice. **To place the same element in multiple glyphs**, select all the glyphs in the Font window, then select the element in the Gallery panel and then click Place. **To replace an element in a glyph with a different one**, select the element you want to replace in the Glyph window, select the element you want to replace it with in the Gallery panel, and then click Replace. **To place an element from the Glyph window to the Gallery panel**, select the element in the Glyph window and click the + button. The selected element will get the default name and appear in the Gallery panel. **To remove an element from the Gallery panel**, 2×CLICK it to open in the Glyph window and remove its name in the Elements panel.
panel.glyph: Glyph panel; The **Glyph panel** shows all the properties of the current glyph. The **Name** field shows a short text identifier for the selected glyph. You can press the Update button to generate a new glyph name based on the glyph’s Unicode codepoint, or edit it manually by typing in the field. The **Unicode** codepoint is a hexadecimal number associated with a character. You can enter it manually, or click the update button for FontLab to try to generate a Unicode value based on the glyph name. The **Unicode character name** uniquely describes a Unicode codepoint. This field cannot be edited. Next, are the **Advance width**, and left and right **sidebearings** of the glyph. **To tether the left, right or both glyph sidebearings to the contours**, click the Bind left sidebearing to contour or Bind right sidebearing to contour or both buttons. Once bound, when you edit the contours in the glyph, the selected sidebearing(s) will remain the same. **Kerning** shows the names of the **first and second kerning classes** (if any) to which the glyph belongs. **Flag** is the glyph cell coloring, used to visually differentiate groups of glyphs. Use the dropdown **to change the flag color**. **Tags** are text labels to differentiate groups of glyphs. You can add any custom or predefined “virtual” text tags to the field. **OpenType class** defines the type of the glyph for the Glyph Class Definition (GDEF) table in the output OpenType font. This is the **Index** of the glyph, i.e. the physical ordering of the glyph in the output font. **Note** is used for adding text comments to the glyph.
panel.guide: Guide panel; The **Guide panel** shows the parameters and properties of the currently selected guideline, font metric (like ascender, x-height, etc.), alignment zone or hint and allows you to edit them. - In the **Name** field, you can enter a name for the selected guideline. Depending on its type, it will have one of the following prefixes — **G** for a glyph (local) guideline, **F** for a font (global) guideline, **E** for an element guideline, **M** for font metrics, **H** for hints, and **Z** for alignment zones. - Use the **Color** dropdown to assign a color to the selected guideline. - click the **Lock/Unlock** toggle to lock/unlock the guideline. A locked guideline can be renamed, but cannot be moved. - **To select the type of guideline** by clicking on one of the buttons – Horizontal, Vertical or Vector. **To generate auto marks**, click Auto markers. **To convert a guideline to short**, click the Short button. - **To change the position of the guideline**, enter the value in the text field. **To change the point of origin of the vector guideline**, enter the X and Y co-ordinates in the fields respectively. - The **Expression** field can be used to enter simple expressions that can be used **to calculate the position of the selected guideline**. - The **Thickness** of the selected guideline is shown in this field. **To change the thickness**, enter the appropriate value in the field. - If the guideline you have selected is vector, this field appears showing the **current angle of the vector**. **To change the angle of a vector guideline**, enter the appropriate value (in degrees) to this field. - If you have selected a vector guideline, this field appears showing the **current length of the vector**. **To change the length of a vector guideline**, enter the appropriate value to this field. - **Guideline tags** are a way to make a font guideline only show up on specific glyphs. - This field shows the position of current **Guideline markers**, and allows you to edit their positions.
panel.history: History panel; The **History panel** records all operations you perform with glyph contours, glyph metrics, kerning or glyph info. The panel shows a list of operations – those on a blue background are currently applied, and the ones on white have been undone. - **Record** takes a snapshot of the current glyph outlines and remembers it in memory for further interpolation. - **Rewind** interpolates back to the remembered snapshot. - **Fast Forward** interpolates from the snapshot (taken with Record) to the current glyph outlines. - **Undo** cancels the last operation on the blue background. - **Redo** performs the first operation on the white background.
panel.image: Image panel; The **Image panel** can be used to apply bitmap filters to image Elements. The options in this panel will be activated only when there is an image element present in the Glyph window. **To select a filter to apply**, use the dropdown menu in the local toolbar. **To show or hide the preview of the filter**, click the Eye button. **To apply the selected filter**, click Apply. The panel has the following filters: - **Sharpen** makes the image sharper and with higher contrast. Use the Strength slider to choose how strongly the filter should be applied. - **Soften** makes the image less sharp, lowers contrast, and blurs it. Use the Strength slider to choose how strongly the filter should be applied. - **Gaussian Blur** blurs the glyph using the Gaussian algorithm. Use the Radius slider **to define the blur degree**, and the Fast Blur option **to strengthen the effect**. - **Find Edges** filter allows you to get the “contour” of an image. - **Reduce Noise** makes images less noisy. Use the Radius slider **to define the best transformation parameters**. - **Despeckle** removes small defects due to dust, or scratches, on a scanned image, and also moiré effects on image scanned from a magazine. - **Threshold** turns color image into black & white by filling the light pixels of the image with white and dark pixels with black. Use the Threshold slider **to move the boundary between “light” and “dark”** Use the dropdown menu **to choose the method of threshold** – Luminosity uses each pixel's red, green and blue channels; Opacity uses each pixel's opacity/transparency component; and Color uses each pixel's hue angle. **To fill the result of the threshold filter with a color of your choice**, use the Colorize pop-up menu. - **Remove Background** tries to separate the element from its background and then clear the background. - **Autotrace** traces bitmap images trying to create smooth and quality outlines. Use the Precision slider **to control the tolerance of the trace** by changing the distance between the generated outline and the edge of the original bitmap. Use the Smoothness slider to help FontLab choose between lines and curves while autotracing.
panel.kerning: Kerning panel; The **Kerning panel** shows the list of kerning pairs defined in the current font, and allows you to preview and modify kerning. **To turn on preview**, click the Show pair preview button in the panel’s status bar on the bottom-right. Now, you’ll see the preview of the pair you select in the list. If the kerning pair you have selected is comprised of kerning classes, the preview will show all members of the class. **To search for a kerning pair**, type the first letter of one of the glyph names in the Filter field. **To see all the pairs that contain a particular glyph on the left**, type the full glyph name followed by a space and then `*`. Similarly, **to see all the pairs that contain a particular glyph on the right**, type the `*` followed by a space and then the full glyph name. **To show only particular sers of pairs**, use the All | All dropdown menu – All shows the full list of pairs; Enc shows pairs that belong to the encoding, codepage, etc. currently selected in the Font window; and, Sel shows only pairs including glyphs that were selected in the Font window. **To select a kerning pair**, click it. **To select multiple kerning pairs**, hold down the SHIFT key and select adjacent pairs, or hold down the Cmd to select any non-adjacent pairs in the list. **To manually adjust kerning for selected pair(s)**, use the left and right **arrow** keys. SHIFT-arrow will change the kerning values by 10 units, CMD-arrow will change them by 100. **To edit the kerning value directly in the table**, 2×CLICK the kerning value, or select a pair and press ↩. **To put a kerning pair in the Glyph window**, open a Glyph Window and select the pair in the panel. The same method works for multiple pairs as well. **To assign a color flag to a kerning pair**, select it from the list in the main area of the panel and choose one of the standard colors or pick a custom color from the color flag menu. If a kerning pair comprises kerning classes that have already been assigned colors, those colors will be shown in this panel. In case you mark such a kerning class in this panel, all three colors will be shown. **To delete selected pair(s)**, click the – button. **To access the local kerning menu**, use the ☰ button at the bottom-right of the panel. The following operations are listed in the menu: - Use **Import Kerning** to import kerning from another font or font master. If the source font includes kerning classes they are imported as well. - **Remove All Pairs** removes all kerning pairs from the font. - With **Compress to Class Kerning**, you can convert flat kerning (i.e. glyph-to-glyph kerning) into class kerning “safely” — only pairs where all class members have identical flat kerning values will be converted into a class kerning pair. This operation is fully reversible using the Flatten Class Kerning operation. - Use **Flatten Class Kerning** to convert all kerning pairs that involve classes (class-to-class, glyph-to-class, class-to-glyph) into a large flat list of glyph-to-glyph pairs. - With **Extend Class Kerning** operation, you can convert flat kerning into class kerning “more aggressively” – glyphs in new classes created by FontLab will inherit the kerning of the previously-defined individual glyph kerning pairs. - The **Adjust** command brings up a dialog box that allows you to automatically change kerning for selected or all kerning pairs. It has three options – you can adjust positive kerning values by several units or percents, you can adjust negative kerning values by several units or percents or you can round kerning values by the selected number of units. To apply changes, select the corresponding option and click OK. - The **Filter** operation opens the dialog box that allows you to remove kerning pairs on the basis of one of these parameters – pairs with small kerning values, pairs containing glyphs from different scripts, or pairs for particular selected script(s).
panel.layersandmasters: Layers and Masters panel; The **Layers and Masters panel** helps you manage the layers and masters in your font. The panel contains a list of all layers and masters for the current glyph. Each item in the list comprises the Name of the layer or master, a Preview, Number of elements in the layer or master, and icons to show whether it is visible, locked, a service layer and if it is shown as a wireframe. Masters have their names displayed in bold, while the special #instances layer has its name shown in grey. Compatible masters have pale green backgrounds in the panel, while incompatible masters have a pale red background. **To show/hide the properties section of the panel**, click the Show layer properties toggle in the local toolbar of the panel. The following properties are shown in the section: - An editable text field for the layer’s **Name**. You can also edit the layer’s name right in the layers list by double-clicking it. - The **Auto layer toggle** with an editable text field for the glyph generation recipe. **To make a layer an auto layer or a manual layer**, use the Auto layer toggle. In the auto layer recipe text field, FontLab’s predefined recipes for an auto layer will be shown in grey; your custom recipes in black. **To modify a predefined recipe**, click the Edit recipe button, modify the text in the field and press Enter. **To go back to FontLab’s predefined recipe**, click the cross-shaped Reset recipe button. **To enter a custom glyph generation recipe for an auto layer** that has no predefined recipe, enter the recipe in the field. - The layer’s **Transparency slider** that controls the layer’s visibility within the FontLab user interface. This does not affect the font export. **To switch between layers and masters**, click their names in the panel. **To modify the order of layers and masters**, DRAG and drop them in the panel. The order of masters in the panel is in sync with the order in the Font Info dialog. **To add a new layer**, click the plus-shaped Add layer button in the status bar. This will bring up a dialog with the following fields and options: - **Name**, where you can enter a name for the new layer. - A set of three icons to define the main **Properties** of this layer — whether it will be a service layer, be locked and if it will be displayed as wireframe. By default, a new layer will be added at the top of the list in the panel. **To put the new layer at the bottom of the list**, click the Put to background button. - You can choose whether the new layer should be added to the current glyph only, selected glyphs or all glyphs. - **Fill new with content of this font** allows you to copy glyph elements from another opened font to the new layer of the current font, and choose whether you would like this copy to be left, right or center aligned. You can also choose the master of that font. If no other font is open at the time, the contents of the currently selected layer of the same font will be copied. - Check the **Make it master layer** if you would like FontLab to name the master in a way that it works as a master. This will be a font master if you add the contents of the opened font, or this a glyph master if you create the layer for just some of the glyphs in the font. - If **Use instance layer if available** is checked and the font is axis-based (i.e. a variable font), the #instance layer is used. - Check the **Rasterize layer to this PPM** and enter the value you need to put the result of the glyphs outline rasterisation to the new layer. **To duplicate a layer in the current glyph**, select it in the panel and click the Duplicate button in the status bar. **To delete a layer**, select it and click the minus-shaped Remove layer(s) button in the status bar. This will bring up a dialog will appear, where you can choose whether you would like the selected layer to be deleted in the current glyph, the glyphs selected in the Font window or Font Map panel, all glyphs, or in the font master. **To hide/show a layer**, select the layer and click the eye-shaped Show button in the local toolbar, or click the same button on the left of the layer preview. **To hide/show all layers**, hold down Cmd and click the Show button in the local toolbar. **To change layer opacity**, use the Opacity slider or the Opacity field in the layer properties section of the panel. **To lock a layer**, select it and click the Lock button in the local toolbar, or click the dot under the Lock icon for that layer. **To unlock a layer**, click the Lock icon in that layer’s row. **To lock all layers**, hold down Cmd and click the Lock button in the local toolbar. **To make a layer a Service layer**, select it and click the Service button in the local toolbar, or click the dot under the Service icon for that layer. **To remove the Service attribute from a layer**, click the Service icon in that layer’s row, or select it and click the icon in the local toolbar. **To add the Service attribute to all layers**, hold down Cmd and click the Service button in the local toolbar. **To show a layer as a wireframe**, select it and click the Wireframe button in the local toolbar, or or click the dot under the Wireframe icon for that layer. **To switch off wireframe**, click the Wireframe icon in that layer’s row, or select it and click the icon in the local toolbar. **To show all layers as wireframes**, hold down Cmd and click the Wireframe button in the local toolbar. **To assign a custom color to a master**, click the color dot in the layer's properties to open the standard Colors dialog box, where you can choose a color. **To automatically match masters for the whole glyph**, click the Match Masters button in the panel’s status bar. **To merge all the layers marked visible in the panel**, click the Merge visible layers button. **To show/hide the mask layers in the panel**, use the Show Mask Layers toggle.
panel.measurements: Measurements panel; The **Measurements panel** is a table where you can keep track of the most important proportions and numerical values of your design. The panel’s rows are predefined **measurements** for uppercase and lowercase letters: vertical and horizontal round and straight stems and their ratios, counters, overshoots, the contrast and some font-wide dimensions. **To show/hide** some measurements, click the Options button at the bottom. These measurements are **for your reference only**, and are independent of the font’s technical values in Font Info. FontLab will save them in your VFC/VFJ, but **not** write any of those values (e.g. stems or Ascender) into Font Info or the exported font. If you have multiple masters, the first column shows the measurements for the current master, then values for all masters are shown. To **switch the master**, 2×CLICK the the column heading. **To enter your own value**, 2×CLICK a cell. To **auto-calculate** some measurements, select the cells in the panel and click the Recalculate button at the bottom. This is useful if you’ve added more glyphs to your font or have entered some custom values that you no longer need. Note: auto-calculation uses Latin glyphs from your font. If you need to note down a **custom measurement** that is not in the list, use **any** predefined measurement row to your liking.
panel.metrics: Metrics panel; The **Metrics panel** shows the name and metrics, i.e. the width, and left and right sidebearings, of all the glyphs in the current font, with an option to preview glyphs one at a time. **To search for a glyph** in the panel, type its name in the Filter field. **To preview a glyph and its metrics**, select it in the list and use the Show metrics preview to open the preview. **To edit a glyph’s width or sidebearings directly in the table**, 2×CLICK the value. **To link the sidebearing(s) of a glyph with another one**, put the second glyph’s name in the sidebearing field instead of a numerical value. **To bind a glyph’s sidebearing(s)**, add an equal sign before the numerical value. **To add a glyph to the Glyph window**, 2×CLICK its name in the panel. If you select the HOH toggle before 2×CLICKing the glyph name, it will open in the Glyph window with additional characters surrounding it for reference: **HOH** for uppercase glyphs and **non** for lowercase ones.
panel.node: Node panel; The **Node panel** shows all the properties of the selected node and allows one to edit them. Click any node on the contour to see its properties in the Node panel. The **Node** field shows the name of the node. Usually nodes do not have names, but if you are going to hint manually or interpolate the font you may need to name your nodes. **To auto-generate the name for a selected node**, click the Generate button to the right of the field. A name will be assigned to the node based on its order in the contour. The **Position** fields show the x and y coordinates the node occupies in the glyph space. If the selected node is a Bézier Control Point (BCP), then clicking on the pin button to the right of the co-ordinates will show its relative position from the on-curve point where it originates. This field shows the **Type** of the selected node – smooth or corner; and X-servant, Y-servant or Genius. **To change the node type**, click the appropriate icon. **To apply the same change to several nodes at the same time**, select all of them and making the required change only once. **To convert a corner node into a Smart corner**, select the node and click the Smart button. Note that this option is only activated if the selected corner is not smooth. **To edit the radius of the Smart corner**, type the new value in the R field.
panel.output: Output panel; The **Output panel** is used by the macro system to show the results of macro program interpretation from the Scripting panel, and by OpenType features compiler to show error messages and warnings that come up from the features written in the Features panel. **To open the contextual menu of the panel**, Right-CLICK anywhere in text area of the panel. The menu has three operations – Copy, Select All and Clear. **To erase all of the panel's contents**, press Clear in the contextual menu, or click ✕.
panel.pairsandphrases: Pairs and Phrases panel; The **Pairs and Phrases panel** can be used with the Spacing modes of the Glyph Window when working on glyph metrics and kerning. **To find a pair in the list**, type in search words in the Filter field. Remember that this search is case-sensitive. **To edit the content of the panel**, click the Texts button on the bottom-right. This will open the **Texts** modal, where you can edit the sample texts. **To go back to the original default texts**, click the ✕ or Reset to defaults button. Click outside the modal to close it. **To load a custom text file**, click the Open Pairs file button and choose the file in the standard open dialog. **To browse phrases in the Glyph window with the Metrics or Kerning tool selected**, use , CMD­·PGUP/CMD­·PGDN (CMD­·FN­·↑ and CMD­·FN­·↓). **To open a phrase/pair from the list in the Glyph window**, select it in the panel. The panel can show two separate text samples, which can be chosen using the selector at the bottom of the panel. **To see pair phrases used for editing kerning**, select Pairs. **To see text phrases used for metrics editing**, select Texts. **To let the application toggle between the two based on the active tool**, select Auto. When the Pairs option is selected, the panel shows the kerning value for each pair, if defined, and offers the following options: - **To compress kerning classes**, click the Compress kerning classes button to the right of the Filter field. - **To autokern one or more pairs**, select the pairs in the list and then click the diamond-shaped Autokern selected pairs button.
panel.preview: Preview panel; The **Preview panel** is a text editor within FontLab, where you can type any text using the current font or a font selected in the Fonts panel, and change its size, alignment, turn its OpenType features on/off, etc. **To open the sidebar with panel settings**, click the button in the top-right of the panel. It contains the following: - The **Content** menu with the following options: 1. **Echo Text** shows the current glyph(s) from the Glyph window or glyph(s) selected in the Font window. 2. **Custom** allows you to type or paste your custom text into the panel. 3. **Context** shows the current glyph between the reference characters: `nn@oo@HH@OO` where `@` stands for the current glyph. Click the wheel to customize. 4. **Text Waterfall** displays custom text (or in its absence, the current glyph(s)) in descending sizes 5. **Glyph Waterfall** displays the current glyph in descending sizes 6. **Clones** shows all glyphs containing the same element references as the current glyph 7. **Anchors** shows all virtual composite glyphs with the current glyph as base When the panel has content set to Echo Text and you click the panel and type in some text, content changes to Custom. Click the button in the bottom-right of the panel to set content back to Echo Text. **To copy the glyphs in the Preview panel to the Glyph window**, open the Glyph window and use upward arrow shaped Copy content to window button, which is available in the Current, Custom, Context, Clones and Anchors modes. **To open one glyph in the Glyph window**, CMD­·2×CLICK on it in the Preview panel. This works in all modes except Text Waterfall. - The **Master** menu allows you to choose between the active layer/master of a variable font, and an instance. **To preview the active layer/master** (as selected in Layers and Masters panel), select Active. **To preview the “virtual instance”**, select Instance. - Use the **Size** menu to choose the font size of the displayed text samples. In the Text Waterfall and the Glyph Waterfall modes, you can set the number of steps in the waterfall, as well as the different text sizes within it. In the other modes, you can choose from a list of pre-defined sizes. - Use the **Align** options to left, center or right align the text you are previewing. - From here, you can apply two **Filters** to the glyphs you are previewing: **Inverted Preview** lets you preview your glyphs in white on a black background; **X-Ray** renders the glyphs as simplified vertical bars so you have a general feel for spacing; **Blurred Preview** lets you set a specified degree of blur on the glyphs. All filters can be applied at the same time. - Use **Horizontal Flip** and **Vertical Flip** to flip your glyphs, to judge your glyph shapes and their stroke balance better. - click **Features**, to open a dialog with a list of all OpenType features in the font. **To select the features you want to preview**, select them in the dialog. Use the Unselect all features if you want to remove all selections. When previewing, make sure the right script is chosen at the bottom of the dialog. **To turn features off**, uncheck the box after Features in the panel. **To see and edit names of glyphs used in the text**, click the Show glyph names button. Once enabled, two bars will appear at the bottom of the panel with the glyph names. You type in the top bar directly to edit the text and the bottom bar shows the resulting glyph names. - Use the **Outline** menu to choose if you would like to see the glyph(s) as regular (choose Outline None for that), or unfilled with a Thin, Normal or Thick outline. To see nodes, click the Show nodes button. - Use the **Tracking** menu to change tracking by predefined values between -100 units to 100 units. - Use the **Slant** menu to slant the glyphs you are previewing by predefined values between -15° to 15°. - Use the **Scale** menu to preview the glyphs as horizontally scaled. 100% means that the glyphs are not scaled at all, negative values will make them narrower, and positive values will make them wider. - Use the **Colors** dropdowns to set the color of the glyph and the background. - Click **Stroke** to display an additional stroke around the glyphs; move the slider to the left to add stroke thickness in background color so the glyphs appear lighter, move it to the right to add thickness in text color so the glyphs appear bolder.
panel.scripting: Scripting panel; The **Scripting panel** is the place to create and run Python scripts in FontLab. Use the hamburger menu in the local toolbar to perform the following operations: - **New Script** closes the currently opened script and clears the panel’s contents allowing you to start a new script - **Open Script** closes the current script and opens the standard Open dialog box allowing you to select and open the script file - **Save Script** saves changes to the currently opened script - **Save Script As** saves the current script to a new file - **Clear Python Context** resets the Python dictionary state before running every new script - **Clear Python Context Now** resets the Python dictionary state. **To run the currently edited script**, click the triangle-shaped Run script button. Use the Search field **to search within the currently opened script**. click the first button on the right-hand side of the Scripting panel's local toolbar **to open the List of scripts**. **To add a folder with scripts**, click the plus-shaped Add scripts folder button. This will bring up the standard Open dialog. If a folder contains at least one file with a .py extension it will appear in the Scripts list. Any scripts you add here will become available in the Scripts Menu, from where you can run them quickly without opening the Scripting panel. **To remove a folder with all its scripts**, select it in the list and click the minus-shaped Remove scripts folder button. **To update the list contents (after you moved or renamed script files in Finder)**, click the Refresh folders button. **To open a script**, 2×CLICK it in the list. **To open the Output panel** to see the result of your macro program interpretation, click the Output panel button on the top-right of the panel. **To open the Python console**, click the Console panel button on the top-right. This is the interactive Python shell where you can communicate with Python using the command line. Unlike the commands you write in the editor that need to be run before you see any response, you can enter Python commands in the Console and get an immediate response.
panel.source: Source panel; The **Source panel** contains the source code of the current glyph and all its layers. In this panel, you can edit a glyph by making changes to its source code. **To select whether you want to see the source code of the current glyph, layer or element**, use the toggle at the top-left of the panel. **To apply the changes you have made to the code**, click Apply. **To revert to back your changes**, click the Revert button.
panel.stroke: Stroke panel; The **Stroke panel** shows stroke attributes for selected elements. **To add a stroke to a selected element**, select Set stroke in the Style toggle. **To choose the stroke color**, use the Outline dropdown menu that opens up a palette of colors to choose from. click the ellipsis button in the palette to open the Color panel. Use the width slider **to modify the stroke width**, or enter a value in the input field on its right. **To choose between round, flat and square cap**, use the cap toggle. **To choose between round, flat and miter joins between strokes**, use the joins toggle. If you choose miter, the input field below will become active for you to input a miter value. **To apply the stroke to the selected element**, click Apply. **To remove the stroke from a selected element**, select No stroke in the Style toggle.
panel.swatches: Swatches panel; The **Swatches panel** is where you can manage standard and custom swatches of colors, and apply them to contours and their fills at the level of entire elements. **To choose which palette to view in the panel**, click the Palette dropdown and choose between: Custom, Standard, Light, Dark and Photoshop. **To select the viewing mode in the panel**, use the Mode toggle to choose between Grid mode and List mode. **To change the contour color of the element**, click the ring in the top left corner of the local toolbar, select the swatch and click Apply, or 2×CLICK the color in the list. If the ring is already colored, and you would like to remove the color, click the small circle with the red diagonal line across it. **To change the fill color of the element**, click the circle in the top left corner of the local toolbar, select the swatch and click Apply, or 2×CLICK the color in the list. **To add a new swatch to a palette**, open the Color panel and mix a color of your choice, then press the plus-shaped Add color button in the status bar of the Swatches panel. **To duplicate a swatch**, select it and then go the palette where you would like to duplicate it and then press the plus-shaped Add color button in the status bar of the Swatches panel. **To remove a swatch**, select it and press the minus-shaped Remove color(s) button in the status bar. **To rename a swatch in the palette**, 2×CLICK its name in the list mode, type the new name and press Enter or click the mouse cursor anywhere else in the window. **To manage palettes**, click the Hamburger button in the status bar, which will open up the **Palettes dialog**. In this this dialog you can: - **To preview a palette in the dialog**, click its name. - **To add a new palette**, click the plus-shaped Add palette button. A new palette will be added. You can type in the name you would like for it, and hit Enter. Once a panel has been created, you can add swatches to it. - **To duplicate a palette**, select a palette in the list and press the Duplicate selected palette button. - **To remove a palette**, select a panel in the list and press the minus-shaped Remove selected palette button. - **To save a palette**, select it in the list and press the Save selected palette to the file button. The standard Save dialog will open: here you can choose where to save this palette and what to call it. Palette files are saved with .palettes extension. - **To open a palette in the Swatches panel**, click the Open palette file button. This will bring up the standard Open dialog, where you can choose any .palettes file to open. - **To reset palettes to default**, click the Reset palettes to default button. **To apply the operations you have done in the dialog**, click OK.
panel.tables: Tables panel; Store, edit and export custom table definitions for arbitrary OpenType tables in the **Tables panel**. Override the tables that FontLab exports by default or add tables that FontLab does not support. Open an existing OTF or TTF and FontLab will decompile font tables except those listed in the Preferences › Open Fonts › Do not import these tables to Tables panel. The table definitions in the TTX syntax will appear in the Tables panel. **To add a definition** for a new table, click +, 2×CLICK the `xxxx` table tag and type your desired table tag. Then input a valid TTX definition for that table in the editing area. **To perform a basic verification** of your custom table definition, select it and click **Verify**. **To remove a table definition**, click –. **To enable** custom table definitions **for export**, turn on their checkboxes. When you export a non-variable OpenType font (OTF or TTF), FontLab will override the tables it generates with enabled custom tables, and will add any enabled custom tables that are suitable for the format.
panel.transform: Transform panel; The **Transform panel** allows you to apply geometric transformations to a selected area or the whole glyph layer when in the Glyph window, or to several selected cells when in the Font window. Before you apply a transformation to a whole layer or selected area, **set the transformation origin using the nine-point reference locator** on the top-left. **To apply the transformations you have performed**, click Apply. Use the Reset button **to change all fields back to their original values**. The following transformations are available in the panel: - **Flip**: **To mirror the layer or selection horizontally or vertically**, use the flip buttons. - **Align**: Use these buttons **to align selected objects vertically or horizontally**. - SHIFT (Offset)++: The offset transformation offers two modes: if the offset location icon is visible, you can **offset to the absolute position** defined by the values you enter for X and Y co-ordinates; while if the offset move button is visible, you can **move by the designated distance** based on the the values you enter for X and Y co-ordinates. **To switch between the offset modes**, click the icon that is currently visible. Positive X and Y SHIFT values move the layer or selection right and up, and negative values move them down and left. - **Scale**: The scale transformation lets you **scale the layer or selection either proportionally and non-proportionally**. Proportional scaling, the default, is represented by proportional scale icon. click the icon to toggle non-proportional scaling, represented by non-proportional scale icon. Values for scaling can be added in either percentage (displayed as %) or absolute units (displayed as u). Clicking on the currently selected method opens a dropdown menu where you can choose the option you prefer. - **Rotate**: **To rotate the layer or your selection**, enter the rotation angle in degrees. Positive values will rotate counter-clockwise and negative values rotate clockwise. You can also click the corresponding icon to enter the rotation value. - **Slant**: **To slant the layer or your selection**, enter the slant angle in degrees. Positive values slant to the right, and negative values slant to the left. You can also click the corresponding icon to enter the slant value.
panel.variations: Variations panel; The **Variations panel** is the primary place where one sets up and controls Variable Fonts. The Variations panel has two main viewing modes: 1. **List view** shows all axes at all times as a list. Within this view, you can perform the following operations: - **To switch between masters and instances**, click the corresponding button below the list. - **To add an instance**, switch to the Instances mode, use the slider to pick a position or enter a numeric value in the field and click the + sign below the list. - **To remove an instance**, in the Instances mode, select the instance and click the - sign below the list. - **To interpolate using different value for X and Y directions**, use the purple and green dials in the panel. The purple dial controls the X direction and the green one the Y direction. The values can be set between 0 to 200, and modified by moving the dial control (represented by a black line) to the left to reduce the value or to the right to increase it. You can also click the number in the middle of the dial to manually enter the value or use the number stepper. 2. **Map view** shows a visual/spatial representation with full detail of up to two axes at once, including position of masters. Within this view, you can perform the following operations: - **To change the axes you want to see in the map**, click the underlined name of the currently selected horizontal or vertical axes and select a different axis from the list. Any axes that are not being shown in the spatial visualisation, appear as sliders below the map. - **To add a virtual instance**, click anywhere on the map and a virtual instance will be added, represented by a blue dot. - **To move the position of the virtual instance**, click it and DRAG anywhere within the design space. Alternately, click a new position in the design space, and the virtual instance will appear there. You can also click the coordinates of the virtual instance, and enter new values by typing them in. **To show all opened fonts belonging to the same family in the Variations panel as if they were master fonts**, click the Append master fonts toggle. This doesn't create master fonts, but only shows the position of the family members in the design space. **To automatically sort contours and points when you add existing fonts as masters**, click the Sort Contours and Start Nodes button. This operation will make the order of elements, contours and points consistent. Note that this operation assumes that both masters have the same number of nodes (only on-curve and TT off-curve points, not handles). **To automatically detect and fix compatibility issues in the nodes of the masters**, click the Check masters geometry button. This operation will detect if there are problems with types of nodes (smooth/sharp), types of segments (line/curve) and take care of situations where elements have been rotated. If something is wrong with nodes and contours compatibility FontLab will try to fix this automatically. **To put the virtual instance back to its default position**, click the Reset button. **To add a glyph master**, click the plus-shaped Add master button in the panel’s toolbar. This will bring up a dialog where you can name the new master, decide whether it is for the current glyph, selected glyphs or all glyphs in the font and choose if the layer should be added even if it exists in the glyphs or not. The new master is added at the position of the “virtual” instance. **To add a font master**, click the Generate instance as master or font button at the far right of the local toolbar. This will bring up a dialog where you can choose whether you want to create a new font master or an instance font at the position of the virtual instance. click Master or Font to choose what kind of master you want to add.
panel.view: View panel; The **View panel** is used to toggle the visibility, snapping behavior and lock status of various details of the Glyph window. The panel is divided into three parts. The top part contains buttons that control details that help in drawing and editing contours: * **Preview Rounding** turns on the Rounding Coordinates mode that turns off fractional precision for outline editing and transformations. * **Power Nudge** turns on the Power Nudge editing mode, which automatically identifies additional nodes and handles that should be nudged along with your selected nodes, and moves them to produce the best possible result. * **Show Tunni Lines** allows you to edit curves using Tunni Lines. * **Suggest Nodes** turns on Suggest Nodes mode, where FontLab shows dotted lines suggesting where to put nodes so they are aligned to existing nodes. * **Suggest Bounds** turns on Suggest Bounds mode, which adds a smart guide on the edge of the element and on the element center. * **Suggest Tangents** turns on Suggest Tangents mode, which suggests that some points that are configured like tangent points, maybe ought to be actual tangent points. * **Suggest Stems** turns on Suggest Stems mode, which adds a smart guide on a distance to the vertical/horizontal line that is equal to the thickness of a standard stem. The second part of the panel allows you to do all the actions available in the View › Show, View › Snap and View › Lock menus along with letting you choose the outline or mask layer for editing. **To choose an outline or mask layer for editing**, click its name in the panel. Markdown and HTML in glyph notes

In glyph notes, you can use a subset of Markdown and HTML. In both Markdown and HTML, there is a concept of _blocks_ and of _inline elements_. Blocks occupy the full width of the document. Each new block creates a line break. Examples of blocks include paragraphs, headings, tables and lists. Inline elements are pieces of formatting that flow with the text inside a block and don’t create a line break. Typical examples of inline elements are emphases (bold or italic) and links.

Markdown blocks

Markdown is plain text with a few non-alphabetic characters that are used to apply formatting. Type Enter twice to get a blank line, which starts a new _Markdown block_.
