sketchboard.focus: Sketchboard; The **Sketchboard** is a new type of window in FontLab. It is an infinite sheet of virtual paper, on which you can organize your graphical assets: sketches, scans, bitmaps and outline graphics (monochrome or color). On the Sketchboard, you can create multiple frames of sample texts in different sizes using any fonts which are currently open in the application. You can edit glyphs within these frames as if you were in a Glyph Window for that font. By default, the Sketchboard opens every time you start FontLab. You can control this with Preferences › General › Open Sketchboard at startup. Use Window › Open Sketchboard to open the Sketchboard window anytime. Use File › Import › Artwork (or ) to import artwork to the Sketchboard. FontLab allows you to import bitmap images in all major image formats, and drawings in EPS, SVG and AI formats. DRAG-DROP a font from the Fonts panel to create a text frame. Or activate a Text tool and CLICK/DRAG anywhere on Sketchboard. You need to have at least one font open. With a text frame active, click Font to change the font, or click the font in the Fonts panel. Use the slider at the left to adjust text size. **To lock/unlock a text frame**, click the Lock button. Text in a locked frame cannot be changed, but you can still change the frame shape, or remove the frame. **To convert a text frame into a Glyph window**, click the maximize button. **To remove the text frame**, click the close button in its upper left corner. Use File › Export › Window Contents to export the content of your Sketchboard. Use Window › Clear Sketchboard to clean up sketchboard.
tool.brush: Brush tool; The Brush tool works somewhat like the brush tool in any bitmap editing program. Click its Toolbar icon or tap B to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). You begin a brush stroke by holding the mouse button, draw the stroke by dragging, and finish drawing it by releasing the button. CTRL­·DRAG on a canvas to resize the brush tip. The results depend on the brush mode selected in the Property bar. With the **Simple brush** mode, the result of your drawing is immediately converted to “outline” contours, and cannot be changed for contours that you have already drawn. Use the Contour tool to edit the contours. With the **Power brush** mode (default), the result of your drawing is a skeleton contour with a **Power Brush** filter applied. In this case, you can edit the skeleton contour with the Contour tool, as well as edit the size and shape of the brush applied to this stroke using the Property bar or the Brush panel. Every time you draw a Power brush contour, you create a new element which includes the contour and the Power brush filter. **To remove the Power brush filter** and only keep the underlying skeleton contour, select the contour and click the **Remove** button in the Property bar or the Brush panel. **To convert the Power brush to final “outline” contours**, select the contour and click the Expand button in the Property bar or the Brush panel, or choose Element › Expand Filters from the menu.
tool.contour: Contour tool; Use the Contour tool to edit contours and other object in glyph layer ‣ Activate: tap A or click 1st Toolbar icon. #### Node - CLICK **node**: select ‣ SHIFT­·CLICK: add to/remove from selection. - 2×CLICK **node**: convert sharp—smooth ‣ SHIFT­·CLICK node: align handles/segments to H/V axis ‣ ALT­·2×CLICK **sharp**: normalize sharpness ‣ SHIFT­·ALT­·2×CLICK sharp: make Smart Corner ‣ ALT­·2×CLICK **smooth**: G2 harmonize node ‣ CTRL­·ALT­·2×CLICK smooth: G3 harmonize handles ‣ SHIFT­·ALT­·2×CLICK smooth: make Genius. - SHIFT­·ALT­·DRAG **smooth** node: slide within segment, **sharp** node: slide within or beyond segment. - BKSP node(s): remove & keep the path unchanged ‣ DEL/FN­·BKSP: break contour & delete adjacent segments. #### Handle - CLICK **handle**: select ‣ SHIFT­·CLICK: add to/remove from selection ‣ SHIFT­·ALT­·CLICK handle: retract - 2×CLICK **handle of sharp** node: align angle to opposite ‣ SHIFT­·2×CLICK **handle**: align angle to H/V axis ‣ ALT­·2×CLICK **handle of smooth** node: slide node to extremum - BKSP/DEL handle(s): convert curve to line segment #### Segment - DRAG point on an **unselected** segment: edit segment ‣ CLICK **segment**: select it if Preferences › Editing › Select segment on outline click is **on**, edit segment with ←↑↓→ if it’s **off** ‣ ALT­·DRAG **selected** segment: duplicate - ALT­·CLICK **curve**: convert PS—TT curve, **line**: convert to curve ‣ SHIFT­·ALT­·CLICK **line**: convert to smooth curve ‣ CTRL­·ALT­·CLICK segment: add node ‣ SHIFT­·CTRL­·ALT­·CLICK: add extremum - 2×CLICK segment: select entire contour ‣ SHIFT­·2×CLICK: add to/remove from selection - BKSP segment(s): remove nodes & keep the path unchanged ‣ DEL/FN­·BKSP: break contour at adjacent nodes & delete segments #### Canvas - ALT­·CLICK **near** segment: select entire contour ‣ SHIFT­·ALT­·CLICK near segment: add to/remove from selection - CTRL­·ALT­·CLICK **near line**: convert to curve, **near curve**: Balance segment - tool.element: Element tool; The Element tool is used to deal with Elements. Click the second Toolbar arrow icon or tap V to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). An element may be a set of one or more contours, a bitmap image, or a sticker. CLICK an element to select it, hold SHIFT to add or remove from the current selection. Nearest node will be highlighted and can be used to properly align element (or selection) to guides and other snap-to structures. Use ←↑↓→ to move the element (selection). Hold SHIFT or MCMD to accelerate movement. 2×CLICK an element to activate the Contour tool and edit element contours. If the element is locked, has a reference and base glyph is available, that glyph will open for editing next to the current glyph. If current element is a group or filter, click any of components to activate it (go one level down). Tap ESC to go one level up.
tool.ellipse: Ellipse tool; The **Ellipse tool** draws ellipses, ovals and circles. Click its Toolbar icon or tap O to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). DRAG to create an ellipse. Hold SHIFT to create a circle, and ALT to start drawing from the center. Hold CMD to create a “white” ellipse that will be unfilled if it’s inside another contour. CLICK to add an ellipse which properties you define in the pop-up dialog box. In the Property bar, choose between a traditional “geometric” ellipse, or a “curved” ellipse, which uses the font **Tension** parameter. When you draw an ellipse, it will be added to the current element. To start drawing in the new element, tap ESC or choose Glyph › New Element from the menu before you start drawing.
tool.eraser: Eraser tool; The Eraser tool is used to erase nodes and/or simplify paths. Click its Toolbar icon or tap 2 to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). - CLICK or DRAG over nodes to remove it. Hold SHIFT to keep “strategic” nodes. - CTRL­·DRAG to resize the Eraser. - CTRL­·CLICK a node, and then click another node on the same contour, and the Eraser will simplify the path between those two nodes - **DRAG on empty canvas** to “draw” a rectangular selector, release the mouse button to remove all nodes inside that selector. Hold SHIFT to protect “strategic” nodes. - ALT­·DRAG on canvas to “draw” a freeform selector, release the mouse button to remove all nodes inside that selector. Hold SHIFT to protect “strategic” nodes.
tool.fill: Fill tool; The **Fill** tool is used to fill or unfill contours and contour-like areas by simple CLICK or ALT­·CLICK. Click its Toolbar icon or tap F to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). Contour-like areas may be formed by self-intersecting contours, closed or open contours. A contour-like area which can be filled (or unfilled) is highlighted every time you move the mouse (with or witout ALT) over it. - CLICK to fill the contour-like area - ALT­·CLICK to unfill - DRAG to fill many areas - ALT­·DRAG to unfill them
tool.guides: Guides tool; The **Guides tool** is used to measure distances between different objects in the drawing area. It may be also use to create pins, anchors and element guides. Click its Toolbar icon or tap G to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). - DRAG from any object on canvas to any other object **to measure distance**. Hold SHIFT to constrain direction. - ALT­·DRAG to create an **element guide**. - SHIFT­·CLICK to add an **anchor**. - ALT­·CLICK to add a **pin**.
tool.kerning: Kerning tool; Kerning tool activates the Kerning mode of the Glyph window. Click its Toolbar icon or tap K to activate it. Kerning pairs can exist between two individual glyphs, two classes, a class and a glyph, or a glyph and a class. Use Font › Generate Kerning Classes... to automatically group similar glyphs into kerning classes, or use the Classes panel to create and edit kerning classes. **To add a kerning pair**, CLICK the second glyph in the pair and then DRAG it closer or farther to the previous glyph in the string. You also can DRAG the “thumb” below the pair. If either of the glyphs is in a class, a pair will be added for that class rather than the glyph. **To create exceptions** from a class kerning pair, hold a modifier key and kern. - **To turn off the first class**, so you kern the first individual glyph with the second class, hold CTRL. - **To turn off the second class**, so you kern the first class with the second individual glyph, hold ALT. - **To turn off both classes** and kern both individual glyphs against each other, hold CTRL­·ALT. Creating an exception adds a new pair that you can subsequently edit in a normal way. **To edit an existing kerning pair** (between classes or glyphs), CLICK the second glyph in the pair and then DRAG it closer or farther to the previous glyph in the string. You also can DRAG the “thumb” below the pair. If either glyph is in a class and a pair exists for that individual glyph, you will be editing that pair. If either glyph is in a class and there is no kerning pair for that individual glyph, you will be editing the class-based pair. You can also edit the kerning value this by using ← for moving the glyphs closer and → for moving them farther. The amount kerned while using the cursor keys can be controlled by keyboard shortcuts: - : 1 unit - : 10 units - : 100 units **To delete a particular kerning pair** (whether it involves classes or simple pairs): - CLICK the second glyph in the pair and type 0 (zero) in the kerning value field in the Property bar. - CLICK the second glyph in the pair and then on the ✕ button next to the kerning value field in the Property bar.
tool.knife: Knife tool; The **Knife tool** is used to insert nodes and break contours. Click its Toolbar icon or tap J to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). **CLICK a node** to break the contour at that node. **CLICK a contour segment** to insert the node. Hold SHIFT to insert a node at the closest extremum. **DRAG from the empty canvas** to form a “knife line.” After you release the mouse, new nodes will be added at all points where this line crossed the outline. Hold down SHIFT to constrain the direction of the “knife line” to 90-degree increments. ALT­·DRAG to add nodes and break contours with the knife. Cutting across a contour in this way will change a closed contour into two open contours. CTRL­·DRAG to “cut apart” the glyph. Cutting across a contour in this way will change a single closed contour into two closed contours.
tool.magnet: Magnet tool; The **Magnet tool** is used to link/unlink nodes to **Power Guides** and to add **hints**. Click its Toolbar icon or tap U to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). Every node may have one vertical and one horizontal link. DRAG from the node to a guide **to link the node to the guide** and make it a power guide. Any node linked to a power guide will follow if you move the guide. If node had a link, it will be replaced with the new one. **DRAG to the canvas** to unlink the node. Use Glyph › Disconnect Power Guides to remove all links in the current layer. Use Glyph › Add Power Guides to automatically add power guides. SHIFT­·DRAG from node/handle to another point or to canvas: add hint. point: add ghost hint
tool.metrics: Metrics tool; Metrics tool activates the metrics mode of the Glyph window where you can edit glyph sidebearings and advance width. Click its Toolbar icon or tap M to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). #### Editing with mouse - DRAG the sidebearing lines of active and inactive glyphs. - DRAG the spacing triangles of an active glyph. - DRAG the image of the active glyph within its advance width, ALT­·DRAG to change the width (turn this off in Preferences › Spacing). #### Editing with keyboard - Hold CTRL and use s to change the left sidebearing by 1 unit. Hold SHIFT to accelerate by 10 units. - Hold ALT and use to change the right sidebearing by 1 unit. Hold SHIFT to accelerate by 10 units. - Hold CTRL­·ALT and use to move the glyph within the advance width by 1 unit without changing the width. Hold SHIFT to accelerate by 10 units. - Hold CTRL­·ALT and use to increase or decrease the advance width by 1 on each side. Hold SHIFT to accelerate by 10 units.
tool.pen: Pen tool; The traditional Bézier **Pen tool** in FontLab is accessible via P and through the toolbar. Click its Toolbar icon or tap P to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). #### New contour - CLICK the canvas to start creating a new contour. Move the mouse to the position of the next node. - CLICK to create a line point. - **Hold** the mouse button and DRAG the mouse to define a curve. New curve handle will be created when you release the mouse button. Hold SHIFT while dragging to to constrain the direction of the line or a handle to axes or 45 degrees. Hold ALT while dragging to move the handle without affecting the handle of the previous curve. - CLICK the starting node of the contour to close it. Or hold the mouse button and DRAG to close the contour and adjust direction of the first node handles. - Tap ESC to stop drawing the contour without closing it. #### Existing contour - CLICK the segment **to add a node**. - **CLICK the first or last** node of an open contour to continue it. - **CLICK the node** to retract the handles. If there are no handles to retract, the node is removed. - **DRAG the node** to make it smooth and adjust handles direction. - ALT­·DRAG the node to make it corner and adjust one handle. Hold SHIFT to constrain handle direction.
tool.pencil: Pencil tool; With the Pencil tool you can create new contours and modify existing contours in a freehand manner. Click its Toolbar icon or tap N to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). #### New contour - DRAG (“draw”) on a canvas to create a new contour. - ALT­·DRAG to add a straight line to the contour. Hold SHIFT to constrain its direction to axes. - End your drawing line on a starting point to close the contour. #### Existing contour Turn on Preferences › Editing › Pen and pencil tools can change contour. Position mouse over an existing contour (or its edge nodes) and start drawing: new stroke will join the contour. End the stroke over the same or another contour to join there.
tool.rapid: Rapid tool; With the **Rapid tool**, you can quickly draw smooth curves. Click its Toolbar icon or tap 5 to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). CLICK for a line, 2×CLICK for a curve. The app knows which nodes should be extremes, and automatically makes smooth curves where needed. Rapid is great for quick drawing of consistent elements, or for intelligent manual tracing of a scan or background image. The Rapid tool draws curves with tension based on the **Tension** parameter in the **Font info** panel or dialog box. The default is a "normal" curve, but you can set a higher percentage to get a super-elliptical curve. #### Adding Nodes - CLICK to add a line. - 2×CLICK to add a smooth curve. - CMD­·ALT­·CLICK to add a tangent node. For every curve segment created, a single control point is added. - **CLICK the first node** of a new contour to close the contour. If Preferences › Editing › Rapid tool remembers last state is on, the Rapid tool adds straight nodes until you 2×CLICK (or CTRL­·CLICK), then it adds smooth nodes until you 2×CLICK (or CTRL­·CLICK) again. Setting this preference gives it two modes, which you can switch back and forth. #### Adding Control Points ALT­·CLICK to add a control point. If control points are added sequentially, the tool will add the intermediate nodes. #### Adjustments At any time during drawing with the Rapid tool, both nodes and control points can be adjusted: - DRAG to move the point. - 2×CLICK to convert straight nodes to smooth and vice-versa. - CLICK" the contour segment to insert a node.
tool.rectangle: Rectangle tool; The **Rectangle tool** draws rectangles and squares. Click its Toolbar icon or tap I to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). DRAG to create a rectangle. Hold SHIFT to create a square, and ALT to start drawing from the center. Hold CMD to create a “white” rectangle that will be unfilled if it’s inside another contour. CLICK to add a rectangle which properties you define in the pop-up dialog box. When you draw a rectangle, it will be added to the current element. To start drawing in the new element, tap ESC or choose the Glyph › New Element menu item before you start drawing. The Eraser toggle button activates the rectangle eraser which, instead of drawing new rectangles, will cut out rectangular shapes out of existing contours.
tool.rotate: Quick Rotate tool; The **Quick Rotate tool** is used to quickly rotate the active contour selection or element, depending one the currently active tool. Tap R to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). **Hold the mouse button** and DRAG to rotate current selection or element. Hold SHIFT to constrain rotation to 15 degree increments.
tool.scale: Quick Scale tool; The **Quick Scale tool** is used to quickly scale the active contour selection or element, depending one the currently active tool. Tap S to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). **Hold the mouse button** and DRAG to scale current selection or element. Hold SHIFT to constrain proportions. Hold ALT to constrain the movement direction to 45 degrees and the scale factor to 100%, 200%.
tool.scissors: Scissors tool; The **Scissors tool** allows you to manually create an overlap or an unlinked corner. Click its Toolbar icon or tap Q to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). **click a corner** to unlink a corner. You now have greater freedom to control the shape of that corner. **ALT­·CLICK a corner** to create a looped corner, similar to an unlinked corner but closed. Both methods create a Fill filter so that only the correct areas are filled. Use Element › Expand Filters to convert these areas to simple contours. **DRAG from one node to another** to create an overlap between these two nodes, i.e. to divide the contour into two overlapping contours. **DRAG from the empty canvas** to marquee-select the nodes where the contour should be divided. You may select 2 nodes to divide a contour into two (e.g. create an overlap between the middle bar of the “E” and the rest), or 4 nodes to create an overlap on an intersection (as in X).
tool.slant: Quick Slant tool; The **Quick Slant** tool is used to quickly slant (skew) the active contour selection or element, depending one the currently active tool. Tap D to activate it (hold the key to activate it temporarily). You have the ability to slant vertically as well. **Hold the mouse button** and DRAG to slant selection or element. Hold SHIFT to constrain slant direction to horizontal or vertical. The starting mouse position defines the slanting origin point.
tool.text: Text tool; The **Text tool** is used to switch the Glyph window to its Text mode, so you can type in the Glyph window and in the Sketchboard. Click the T Toolbar icon or tap T to activate it, tap ESC to return to the previous tool. With the Text tool, you can type or paste any text. If your font does not contain glyphs for some characters, character templates will appear instead. 2×CLICK a character template to create an actual glyph for it, so you can start designing it. Press CMD­·L to input a glyph that is related to the character before the text cursor. Press and hold any letter key to input glyphs related to that letter. Tap / to input a glyph by its glyph name. Tap ++#++ to input a glyph by its Unicode codepoint. Press CMD­·F to input a glyph using various criteria.
tool.transform: Free transform; Use Free tranform to apply transformation to selected contours or elements. Use Tools › Free Transform (CMD­·T) to activate or simply 2×CLICK selected contours. Controls for contour transformation have **blue** color, element transformation is **green**. The green rectangle means the transformation applies **only** to this particular instance of the element. Other elements referencing to the same contours will stay unchanged. DRAG the body of the control area to **move** selection. Hold SHIFT to constrain movement. DRAG corners to **scale**. Hold SHIFT to scale unproportionally. DRAG edges to scale in one direction. DRAG near the contours to **rotate**. CMD­·DRAG controls on any edge to **slant**. CMD­·DRAG corners to apply **perspective transformation**, hold SHIFT to allow free movement. DRAG the ✕ control to define center of rotation. Tap ↩ to accept (or CLICK the empty canvas), tap ESC to cancel the transformation.
tool.zoom: Zoom tool; Use the Zoom tool to change view area of the Glyph window. Press CMD­·SPACE to activate zoom tool, then CLICK to zoom in or DRAG to define are which you want to zoom. ALT­·CLICK to zoom out. Tap Z to quickly zoom in the area below cursor. Tap X to zoom out. These keys are active in any tool and any mode.
welcome: Welcome to FontLab!; Open or create a new font using the **File** menu, or using the **Welcome** dialog, which you can open from the _FontLab_ menu on Mac or _File_ menu on Windows. #### Learn FontLab Move your mouse pointer over a user interface element such as a text field or a button, and wait for a while to see a short **tool tip**. Point at a UI element and **hold F1** to see an extended **help tip** that appears until you release the key. We have added help tips to many UI elements, with more to come! On macOS, you may need to use FN·F1 — to use just F1, turn on Apple menu › System Preferences… › Keyboard › Keyboard › Use F1, F2, etc. keys as standard function keys. **Tap** (briefly press) **F1** (or FN·F1), or click the circled **?** in top-right of this panel, to turn on **Quick Help mode** that shows help tips as you explore the user interface with your pointer. Tap the key again to turn Quick Help mode off. To show help tips in **large font size**, turn on Preferences › General › Show keystrokes and Apply. Press SHIFT·F1 or SHIFT·FN·F1 to open this **Help panel**. Then open a tool or a dialog, or click an open panel, and read its description in the Help panel. Press the key combination again to hide the Help panel. From the **Help** menu, choose **User Manual** to open the FontLab help center for more extensive documentation. Choose **Support** to contact us directly with questions or problem reports. Choose **Forum** to ask other users for tips and suggestions, or share your own!
